However, like a man who's finally holding the winning lottery ticket, Joe finally seizes an opportunity to turn things around for himself. The big question of the film is: will he cash it in?Princess Ann is at the other end of the spectrum. A European princess of vast wealth and prestige has grown weary of the in-and-out days of drudgery, tedious schedules, and evenings of crackers and milk for a snack. Every day seems the same as the last. She decides to escape from her life and unwittingly finds herself in Joe Bradley's apartment after he mistakenly thinks she's just a silly, drunken girl.Upon finding out who she really is, Joe decides to do whatever it takes to stay within Ann's circle (as she is operating under the name of Anya) to get the story of the year. Upon hearing Ann's desire to have some time around Rome, he wisely suggest a holiday; a day to do all of the things she's always wanted. It's here that the story really takes off and the chemistry between Joe and Ann begins to deepen.The film is simply a wonderful delight. We feel as though we've been given our own holiday in this classic fest. However, as with all good things, it must all come to an end. I was thrilled the Wyler didn't go for any cheap gimmicks or tricks to keep them together or bog the generally light story down in needless melodrama.The last scene of the film is perfectly done with perfect tough and sweetness. The brief looks and exchanges between Joe and Ann demonstrates that neither one has given over to selfishness or greed. Joe assures her (after she realizes who he is) that he has no intention of ever writing the story. And Ann assures him that, not only is her trust and faith in him warranted, but that she will always cherish him and the day that they had together.As good as the cast is, it really is Audrey Hepburn who makes the film work so well. I truly cannot imagine any other actress in this role. She was the epitome of sweetness and innocence mixed with a rebelious nature not unlike a young woman who's finally grown up a bit by the film's end. She sees the life she could have but knows that she can never have it. The moment between Hepburn and Peck in the car before she returns to the palace is tender and heart-breaking and performed perfectly by both. But it's the end that I found truly touching, as a last look is exchanged in a slightly tearful farewell.Of all of Hepburn's work, this one is still my favorite, and it's a film and a story that I never get tired of. For every once in a while, I treat myself to a holiday by watching this movie one more time.

How do you feel when you create something so beautiful but you can't take the credit for it? How painful it must be when and you have to let someone else take the highest award for your creation? Well, Dalton Trumbo got the credit and an academy award for the screenplay of 'Roman Holiday' 40 years after the movie and almost 20 years after he had died of a heart attack. What a tragedy!This was Audrey Hepburn's first major motion picture for which she received an academy award as well. One of the most beautiful and graceful actresses of our times who plays the role of Princess Ann who sneaks out one night during her official visit to Rome. Her encounter with Joe Bradley, a reporter for an American newspaper is what becomes her "roman holiday". Most of the film was shot in Rome at real locales and has a wonderful feel to it. I was looking at some Piaggio brochure and it was mentioned against one of the models 'Audrey Hepburn rides this model in roman holiday', that's the kind of pride Vespa Piaggio takes about the fact that they were a part of this movie. That sure was a very beautiful scene and sticks in your mind like so many others in the movie.Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn together looked fabulous in this one. Easily one of my all time favorite movies.

reviews.review_title: One of the all-time great romantic comedies
reviews.content: "Roman Holiday" proved to be one of the most completely enjoyable romantic comedies I've ever seen. It was funny and romantic, with great performances all around. Gregory Peck was great as usual, as was supporting star Eddie Albert. In her debut (and Oscar-winning) role, it's no wonder that we saw more of the great Audrey Hepburn. Even today, this film's plot and writing seems fresh and original. One reason I enjoyed this film so much was because few films of this type can make me care so much about the main characters. Although the ending disappointed me slightly and wasn't the ending I would have chosen, I realize that the film went for a more realistic and believable ending, and I compliment Hollywood for that. If you want the film to end perfectly, it may not be for you. However, if you're looking for an otherwise enjoyable classic movie and a sense of realism in the film-making, this film is definitely recommended.***1/2 out of ****

The plot of this movie has been reused so often it's become a stereotype; a prince or princess tired of the stuffy royal routine sneaks off to see what life is like outside the palace walls. Usually the result is an obnoxious royal whining about housework or expecting to still be waited on hand and foot by others, but this is the exception. Audrey Hepburn's princess is charming and innocent. She takes delight in trying for the first time simple things others take for granted, like eating ice-cream, dining at a quaint open-air cafe, going sightseeing, even just getting to choose her own haircut (which is completely adorable!), and it's that childlike wonder of experiencing life for the first time that draws us into her character. I'm sure that's also what draws Gregory Peck's reporter in. He sees nothing wrong, at first, with selling out the young princess for the sake of a bet and a news scoop, but through the course of the day's events, he finds himself genuinely falling for her. In the end, love wins out, and though he really could use the money, he finds he can't betray her. In a more modern movie, we would expect the two to run off together, but in a way I think it's better as it is. She knows it would be selfish to abandon her family and countrymen that way, and that's not who she is. But even good responsible princesses could use a holiday once in a while.

This is a very delightful movie about a young princess who, tiring from her perfect life, escapes one day from her palace and the journalist who finds her. On recognizing that this can be the scoop of a lifetime, he hides her identity and they proceed to spend a truly memorable time in the streets and among the monuments of Rome. They are accompanied by his friend who is a photographer. Hepburn won an Oscar for her portrayal of the princess but for me Gregory Peck was the best part of the movie. He is excellent in the comic scenes and truly mind blowing in the romantic ones. The scenes are shot lovingly and the direction by Wyler who would go on to create the epic Ben Hur six years down the line is masterly.The one scene which still lingers in my mind is the first kiss between the two leads. It will give you goosebumps. This is a true classic, one which hasn't lost its magnificence even 70 years down the line. 4 out of 5 for this. Very highly recommended for all the rom-com lovers.

This movie may have been an Oscar winning boxoffice success in it's day (1953) but in the 21st Century it's a real yawn. Here's the story - working class American reporter meets spoiled royal princess, they fall in love, it can't be, end of movie.Audrey Hepburn is beautiful as Princess Ann, Gregory Peck as the reporter looks old enough to be her father, Eddie Albert is just goofy. The story isn't remotely believeable. And how did the reporter afford that small but very nice apartment with a huge terrace?Skip it!

This is a beautifully charming comedy film that everybody knows as the film that made Audrey Hepburn's career. It was also superb advertising as everybody then ran out to buy on of them vespa scooters. This is one of Audrey's best films, I feel in future films she tended to over play her roles somewhat but in this she is just perfect. The soundtrack of this film is equally amazing, kudos to Georges Auric on that score (pardon the pun), I guess if modern soundtrack styles were applied to this film we might have ended up with Perry Como some Dinah Shore and even some Frankie Laine, but in my opinion that would just have ruined it. I truly the believe that Auric's film score just gives a little bit of extra magic to this movie. Can I say looking at the way modern films are made this one is just simply put a miracle.

reviews.review_title: " There is too much pomp and ceremony to this position, I wish it would all go away "
reviews.content: There are many stories concerning the Royal families of Europe, and occasionally a sliver of truth concerning one of them is factual which lends much to this Hollywood offering. This story is a comedy and called " Roman Holiday. " It was originally written by Dalton Trumbo the Black Listed screen writer, but the movie credit was given to others. However with William Wilder as director little is lost from the original script. The story is of a down-on-his-luck American writer named Joe Bradley (Gregory Peck) who happens upon a sleeping Princess (Audrey Hepburn) who has escaped from her strict, regimented and enclosed life behind the royal gates. Realizing his incredible luck, Joe takes full advantage of the situation, but pretending he knows nothing of her real Identity and hopes to acquire a Scoop for his newspaper. Enlisting the help of Irving Radovich (Eddie Albert), a close photographer friend, he takes the Princess out for a Holiday. Although it's a comedy, dull slap-stick adds little to the mostly slow, but poignant sympathetic situations. The main emphasis zero's in on Peck and Hepburn's increasing romantic tension. As a result, their Holiday is a fun escapade through the streets of the eternal city. One which becomes more memorable as the years accumulate for their fans. ****

reviews.review_title: A breathtaking day in the Eternal City or What the princesses want!
reviews.content:
Melodrama. The first and one of the most famous roles of the beauty Audrey Hepburn. So it's time to finish the marathon of paintings with her participation. What can I say - it was interesting, exciting, and even fun to some extent. This picture was specially left "for dessert" in order to get the maximum viewing pleasure - and did not regret it. And here is my brief opinion - a breathtaking day in the Eternal City. I note right away that I do not intend to talk about the minuses, because there are none. Well, it's more true, though it will already be in the field of nit-picking, so I don't intend to hammer your head with them. Therefore, I will dwell on the expressive virtues of this legendary picture, which for all the years that have passed since its release in hire has become a classic of world cinema.
So here they are:
1. Romantic story - the young Princess Anna arrives on an official visit to Rome, but endless receptions, presentations, social events tire her so much that one day she decides to escape. She is found by a casual passerby who turns out to be an American journalist who has a unique chance to collect exclusive material. Will he be able to do this? How will a princess hide her social status? What comes of all this? Pure romance, uncomplicated, maybe a little pathetic and pretentious, but so attractive. The princess and the journalist, in two hours of timing, go through a series of funny, dramatic, and simply interesting adventures, which are not only interesting to watch, but even want to travel to the other side of the screen and join the heroes. Many critics, and the audience both here and in the West, consider this romantic story the best in the cinema - I strongly disagree! I have a story that interrupted this, but this is pure subjectivity. Personally, I liked this story, but I simply have no right to call it the best, because my heart has already chosen another!
2. Rome - the first Hollywood picture, which was completely shot in Europe - and this is felt. The beauty of the Eternal City is presented in all its glory. Connoisseurs of history and tourists will surely recognize many of the monuments where the main characters visited throughout the painting. And although not all of them were able to be shown, this fact delivers aesthetic pleasure. Even despite the fact that the picture is black and white, she managed to convey the full power of the charm of these ancient ruins left over from the once greatest empire on planet Earth.
3. Humor - I was very pleased with this fact, because all the comedic moments were a success. Absurdities, sometimes antics, sometimes tough jokes - all work on the images of heroes. No comedic moment will cause a violent reaction here, but a light smile and laughs are definitely guaranteed for you!
4. Final - but it was really a surprise. He is happy on the one hand and sad on the other. But it is definitely logical. The whole mood of the picture and the behavior of the main character hint at him. I still have not decided how I feel about him. On the one hand, I understand the heroes and I'm sad, on the other, I'm happy, because sometimes circumstances are much stronger than us. I counted on the well-known outcome, but this is a fairy tale, a tale of a princess and a commoner, magnificent, unforgettable, sensual. Here it is.
A little about the main characters:
1. Princess Anna performed by Audrey Hepburn is the young heir to the throne. A little eccentric, partly naive, spoiled girl who wanted adventure on her own head. How could she know what this hasty decision would lead to? The beautiful Audrey beautifully played the young princess, who during the timekeeping was transformed and experienced love - this is an eternal feeling, without which it is very difficult for a person to remain himself. Bravo Audrey!
2. Joe Bradley performed by Gregory Peck - a journalist who picked up a stranger and brought to his own house, until he accidentally found out who she was. At first, he behaves prudently and cynically, which results in a sea of various funny situations, but gradually awareness comes to him. Gregory perfectly embodied the role of man as one of the most unscrupulous professions on Earth. At first you cannot empathize with his hero, but the further, as they say, the more interesting. Bravo Gregory!
The picture was a resounding success at the box office, only in America the fees were quite modest. Even the premiere in the Soviet Union was very warm. Even the censors of the party were concerned about the extraordinary success of this melodrama. It was melodramas, not a romantic comedy, the script for which was written by the famous Hollywood screenwriter Dalton Trumbo, who in those years suffered greatly for "sympathy for the Communists", because of which his name was crossed out of their picture captions. Only two decades later, justice was restored.
It's time to take stock of this marathon, and I'm confused. I can't choose the best picture with Audrey, although I looked at five of them, and in all Audrey was amazing and gorgeous. I do not know what to do!
As a result, we have an excellent melodrama about the breathtaking adventures of a young princess and a cunning journalist, with a good romantic story, excellent views of the Eternal City and wonderful acting. Audrey and Gregory duet - great!

Roman Holiday is one of the very few "flawless" films in the history of film making. In Audrey Hepburn's first American film, she steals the show. It is impossible to take your attention off her. Not only is she beautiful, but talented as well. She has a great sense of timing, and this is so important for any actor in a comedy. Each scene is beautifully shot in the city of Rome, making it a delight for the eyes. Gregory Peck has incredible chemistry with Hepburn, and is a delight to watch. I would recommend this film to anyone; young, old, male or female. This is a timeless classic and the platform from which Hepburn became a huge star and made her mark on American film, fashion, and style.

reviews.review_title: Absolutely Charming, ahead of it's time
reviews.content: Audrey Hepburn is the real star of the show here and she remains a fascinating figure to watch. A jumble of contradictions, if there's such a thing as "strong vulnerability" or "active passivity" she had it. Plus, as she rambles around Rome her reactions seem completely unguarded, which is a pretty amazing thing, really, for a movie actor to pull off. (I am less impressed with Peck here, who, while doing a professional job of it, just seems miscast. The role is crying out for somebody who's more convincing playing seedy, like William Holden, say.) A very clever movie that has an interesting subtext (the movie is in many ways a quiet celebration of the lies we tell each other, and sees love as a kind of mutually-accepted illusion) and seems ahead of it's time: this is the first movie I know of to see not just riches, but more specifically celebrity, as a kind of prison.Rome looks lovely here.

reviews.review_title: Do you have a silk nightgown with rosebuds?
reviews.content: Directed by William Wyler, "Roman Holiday" stars Audrey Hepburn as a royal princess who visits Rome. Here she meets Joe Bradley (Gregory Peck), an expatriate American reporter. Hepburn's character wishes to be free of royal duties for a day, a whim which Bradley facilitates.The 1950s witnessed a wave of "travelogue movies" ("Summertime", "To Catch a Thief" etc), a wave to which "Holiday" belongs. Much of the film consists of Hepburn and Peck frolicking amidst beautiful Mediterranean scenery, she elegantly poised, he immaculately chiselled. Charming, frothy and fantastical, the film was one of Wyler's attempts at emulating the comedies of Billy Wilder and Ernst Lubitsch. "Holiday" finds Hepburn as a commoner playing a princess playing a commoner. In real life she was the sickly child of a dead aristocratic line. She was then plucked from obscurity to become the princess of 1950s/60s style and fashion. It's a rags to riches journey which most of Hepburn's films ("Sabrina", "My Fair Lady", "Funny Face" etc) are themselves about.7.9/10 – See Vincente Minnelli's "The Clock" for a better, similar picture. For a more subversive take on such "travelogue escapism", see Antonioni's "Beyond the Clouds" or the films of Wim Wenders.

What a treat! Especially to see this in a movie theater! Gregory Peck is Joe Bradley, a down on his luck news reporter stationed in Rome with big plans for fame, fortune, and a new opportunity. The always beautiful and elegant Audrey Hepburn is Princess Ann, with the Royal Family in Rome, rebellious, shy, and under enormous pressure to remain dignified and under control. Princess Ann is tired of living in the fish bowl, and one night, she escapes the compound and meets Joe, who thinks she's drunk (but actually sedated).Joe, in a moment of weakness, takes her back to his apartment to let her sleep off the "hangover". Only the next morning does he realize the true identity of this stranger. He calls his friend Irving (warmly played by Eddie Albert) in a scheme to get the big scoop: a story and pictures of the young princess doing very un-princess like things.Princess Ann goes along with the ploy, not knowing their true motives but realizing an opportunity to be no one.We follow them throughout the day as they laugh, play, and bound. Joe and Irving must make the difficult choice: Business or Friendship?

This is movie is a great fairy tale, and it is probably the best to have been adapted to cinema. The scenario of Dalton Trumbo is simply amazing filled of very funny dialogues and William Wyler also made this movie gripping until the end. Like usual the performance of Audrey Hepburn is excellent, and you can hardly make less than 8 to this movie even if you search for mistakes. Seriously, it is worth a watch for a ton of reasons, and you won't regret it.

reviews.review_title: A captive Princess gets a day off.
reviews.content: Amazing, I know, that in my almost 60 years of movie-watching I had never seen "Roman Holiday" until now. But it is on a recent list of "best" movies so I snagged my opportunity when I found it at my local public library. The DVD is very nicely done, with interesting extra features.Just in her early 20s, this is the film that got Audrey Hepburn noticed. Gregory Peck was approaching 40, and Eddie Albert was approaching 50. But the three of them are just wonderful together in this caper.Gregory Peck is Joe Bradley, in Rome with the American News Service. By all indications, including owing 2 months' back rent on his very modest apartment, the money was not flowing in.Audrey Hepburn is British Princess Ann, heir to the throne, forced by "duty" to make appearances all over but otherwise very tightly controlled. She longed to break out of her chains.One evening, feeling particularly moody, her handlers gave her a shot of something to help her sleep, but she managed to crawl out of a window at the British Embassy in Rome and escape by hiding in a laundry truck that shortly left. She found herself at night in a strange place and as luck would have it was discovered by Bradley as she slept on a bench. He tried to get a taxi to take her somewhere but practically incoherent she ended up sleeping at his place.At first Bradley has no idea who she is, but when he realizes she is the Princess sees an opportunity for a real story and some real cash, $5,000. He recruits his friend, Eddie Albert as photographer Irving Radovich, to help out (for 25%) by snapping exclusive photos of the Princess on her one-day "holiday" all around Rome. She thought he was just being nice to help her sight-see, he looked at it as strictly a business opportunity.Ann finds out how it is to live like a real person, but in the end she returns to her Princessly duties, and finds out who Bradley and Radovich really are, as she fields questions from them and a host of other newsmen. Their secret safe, as Bradley has too much respect for her to sell the story, and both their lives are changed for the better, as a result of this one magnificent day.

Roman holiday is one of the most incredible movies I have ever seen. I came across this movie by chance. I watched Charade starring Audrey and Cary Grant. Audrey's acting in that movie impressed me. That's why I decided to watch Roman holiday too even though it is quite old. To be honest, I wasn't really looking forward to watching this movie because it is an old black and white movie. However, I was wrong. I was almost crying when I finished watching this movie. I have never seen a movie, which had so much romance, comedy and emotional drama at the same time. I strongly recommend that you should watch this movie if you are a young person who does not really like old movies.

reviews.review_title: This has, for me, a sad tone at the end.
reviews.content: "Roman Holiday" is Princess Anne's story, one mad-cap day of freedom away from a highly constricted life. She is intelligent, sensitive, aware of her duty as 'heir to the throne', yet she yearns for a 'normal' life. With reporter Joe Bradly's help, she has her mad-cap day of being normal, and finds love. They both do. In the end, Bradly gives her unselfish love in the form of a 'gift' that costs him quite a bit of money.And for the first time, after seeing this film about 10 times, it struck me that it has a sad tone. That was the only day in her life that she has had, or will ever have, pure unqualified, unselfish love. Even her eventual marriage will most probably be for 'reasons of state' rather than for love.

A flat-out amazing movie. William Wyler, famed director of "Ben-Hur" [1959] among others, is the perfect director for this film. While not noticeable in the way some films of the 60's and 70's were, the directing technique in this movie is original and very good. Wonderful use of the camera for sure. Especially in the exciting climax of the movie. Also it was filmed in beautiful black and white that really adds to the picture.The screenplay by Ian McLellan Hunter and John Dighton is very charming. With a script this good you can see why so many marquee stars of Hollywood were attracted to this project. Many memorable scenes stem directly from the witty dialog.The acting in the film is, of course, amazing. Audrey Hepburn screen debut is the one she received her, regrettably, only Oscar for. But boy did she deserve it. As soon as I start talking about Ms. Hepburn I speak only in hyperbole. Obivously the best actress ever, bar none, Her screen presence, charm and beauty radiate off the screen. Gregory Peck does a pretty good job himself though. He slowly becomes intoxicated with Ms. Hepburn throughout the movie, as I'm sure any man would in a similar situation. Eddie Albert is thrown into the mix for some comic relief and he is quite funny but the movie is really about the two leads.Set in the stunning beauty of Rome this is one of my all-time favorite romantic comedies. What a great film. Truly a classic.

reviews.review_title: My Favourite Movie of ALL Time!
reviews.content:
I love this movie with all my heart, Gregory Peck, the most charming man that ever walked the Earth, and Audrey Hepburn, the most dazzling and elegant woman to blow humanity away.
Some people call this movie totally 'cliche', but a princess leaving a man that she loves to do her duty is cliche? No.
Every single aspect of this movie should be loved and cherished. The seen with the Wall of Wishes is clearly my favourite, as it was NOT acted out nor scripted.
Audrey and Gregory's chemistry is incomparable and totally love-able. I rate this 10/10, and would give infinity if I could.
Both of them simply just appearing makes my heart melt, and their kiss is full of such serenity and beauty, unlike movies these days *coughs* 50 Shades of Gray. Their simplicity and poise is so lust, proper, and dignified.An incomparable classic full with modish, discerning, and cultivated love and adventure. May both Miss Audrey Hepburn and Mr. Gregory Peck rest in peace and know that they are loved for eternity.

reviews.review_title: A movie with an extremely peaceful end
reviews.content: If you want to watch a beautiful movie that has a beautiful ending and makes you happy, this is the one.Audrey Hepburn's acting is excellent. You can very well believe she is a princess. Her reactions when she find out she slept in Gregory's clothes are quite entertaining. Gregory Peck is sometimes beside Audrey sometimes behind her in attention being given, but that's completely fine.The circumstances of how she meets Gregory and runs away from the palace are very nicely shown, so are their trip throughout Rome. The movie was purposely shot in black and white as they didn't want the attention to shift from the couple towards the beautiful city.In regards to the ending, I thought that Audrey will find out about his lies but in the end they will get back together and eventually marry all that because that's usually how the story in such movies ends. But I was pleasantly surprised and happy to see that this was not the case at all!In the end they both know their place. The final scene of the press conference was very beautifully shot, and gives a fitting end to a wonderful movie. In my opinion the final scene catapults the movie to even bigger heights than it already was before.All in all, a very very good movie to watch, and one which will leave you at peace in the end.

This is a great movie!  I have always been a Gregory Peck fan, but "Roman Holiday" made me love him even more!  When you think of all the great parts he played, this certainly ranks as one of the highest.  Audrey Hepburn is wonderful in her Oscar-winning performance, as is Eddie Albert in his Oscar-nominated role.  This movie gets a 10-10.  For all of you who love a touching 'roman'ce, "Roman Holiday" is for you!

If you're not an Audrey Hepburn fan, this movie may convert you.Her performance here defies description.  At this stage in her career, she is so genuine and pure -- yet to be influenced by too many acting lessons or too many directors.Her natural talent displayed here is nothing short of magical.  She begins this story as a precocious teen, resenting her royal responsibilities, and gradually blossoms into a very worldly, very sensual young woman.I defy any man to watch this movie and not fall in love with her.

I caught this film at a local theater viewing recently. I had never seen it and knew nothing about it going in, but it was great! You're told in the introductory credits that it was shot in Rome in its entirety, and the story features a young foreign princess who travels to Rome where she winds up escaping from her scheduled mundane royal life for a day to get into adventures with a gentleman who befriends her. Little does the princess realize that her beau is a reporter who is keen to her game of hooky.Audrey Hepburn shines in this movie, and Gregory Peck is impeccable. The film is in black and white but features good cinematography for its day. The script is lighthearted and fun. 8/10 stars!

reviews.review_title: Someone has to be The Grinch
reviews.content: First, the good stuff.  (1)  The shots of Rome are wonderful.  One can hardly believe it's the same crowded metropolis that it is today.  Let's hear it for 1953!  The other recent film that shows Rome so beautifully is "The Talented Mr. Ripley".  (2)  As usual, Audrey Hepburn is just wonderful. She came from some beautiful planet.  The scene when she wakes up in Gregory Peck's apartment is lovely: I just think of how she tries to cover herself with the blanket and misses covering her posterior.  Just great. The scene at the "Mouth of Truth" is fantastic.Second, the bad stuff.  (1)  Gregory Peck just does not fit Audrey Hepburn. He lacks her light touch.  He is a bit wooden --- just like Humphrey Bogart in Sabrina.  I thought that Gary Cooper was a better romantic lead in "Love in the Afternoon".  (2)  I am always uncomfortable when Italian characters are portrayed as a type of buffoon.  (3)  A princess on the lam is a great idea, but monarchy as a real institution, as portrayed in this movie, has very little meaning anymore.  I realize that Queen Elizabeth was crowned a couple of years before this movie was made, and the pomp, mystique, and the royal ethic of self-subordination were probably still very much alive.  But now all that is quite tarnished for whatever reason.  Princess Ann's transformation and maturation therefore seem artificial and dated.What can I say?  As a Hepburn film, it's a 10.  As a movie, it's a 5 or 6.

If there is such thing as a perfect film, this is it! Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn, how could it get any better? Peck and Hepburn have such great chemistry and work so well together. I personally wished they would have made another film together. This film really proves that Gregory Peck can do comedy. Some people feel he is a better 'serious' actor. But Peck really shows his funny side in Roman Holiday.This movie has everything from laughter to tears. It is not a romantic movie that is long and boring, with tons of kissing. The romance in it is perfect.So check out Roman Holiday, you will love it!

reviews.review_title: "I will cherish my visit here in memory as long as I live."
reviews.content: Roman Holiday is a strong film in all areas. It gives two actors an incredible script and puts it to the beautiful backdrop of Rome to make one of the most memorable rom coms and creates two instantly recognisable characters. The combination of both humour and genuine sentimentality makes this film highly memorable and definitely worth the watch if you get the chance. The plot outline is simple enough. A sheltered princess escapes her guardians meets a boy and begins to fall in love. It's a clichéd story that's been done before the film was released and has been reused many times since. But whilst it does meet the clichés of the Romance genre, it uses them well and proves that the clichés can still be great. Together Peck's great charm mixed with the kind and playful nature of Hepburn makes for one of the most memorable romances put to film. At first they don't seem to have any real affection for each other with both of them using one another for their own benefit. Hepburn lies so she can have a day of freedom and Peck lies as he wants nothing more than a good story.But over the course of the film we really begin to see genuine affection grow between the two. It never feels forced, but instead evolves naturally as they begin to enjoy the others company more and more over the course of the day by becoming more playful with one another and bonding because of it. Largely this is because both Peck and Hepburn's brilliant on screen chemistry with moments like the Mouth of Truth scene being entirely improvised to add realistic charm to all their scenes. Mixed with this is the beautiful and romantic backdrop of Rome with their exploration over the city containing many memorable and beautiful settings. Everywhere they go is as new to the leads as it is to us allowing us to experience their journey with them. On top of this the beautiful sights go with the couples growing relationship to create an even greater feeling of romance.

reviews.review_title: Elizabeth Taylor would have been better
reviews.content: I know Roman Holiday won Audrey Hepburn an Oscar and made her an instant star, so I might be the only person in the world to say this, but I wish the producers had won out on their original choice to play the princess: Elizabeth Taylor. The second choice was Jean Simmons, but she couldn't get out of her studio contract, so I've read, and William Wyler became attached to Audrey Hepburn's screen test. The rest is history.Think about it, though. Elizabeth Taylor would have been perfect! She absolutely could have handled the royal scenes, and when the princess runs away from the palace in search of adventure, young Liz would have given a wonderful, wide-eyed, innocent, curious, charming, mischievous performance—a performance I didn't feel from Audrey Hepburn. Audrey came across as entitled, snobby, and worst of all, knowledgeable. The princess is supposed to be innocent, with a thirst for knowledge. She wants to see Italian landmarks, smoke her first cigarette, go to a nightclub, and get her hair cut. Audrey seems like she's already done all those things. Liz would have been better. And Jean Simmons would have been perfectly fine.Audrey's performance aside, there are two other actors who share the screen with her: Gregory Peck and Eddie Albert. They play a slacking reporter and photographer who discover the runaway princess and plan to write a front page news story about her. The rapport and snappy dialogue between them is pretty funny, but overall, I find Roman Holiday an overrated film. It's a light romance, and somehow was elevated to multi-Oscar winning, ultra-classic status. Whenever I watch it, I try and take it for what it is.

Basically, "Roman Holiday" is one of "those movies". You know the ones. You have seen the picture umpteen-million times and practically can say the dialogue along with the actors BUT it comes on the TV and even though you missed the first twenty minutes and it's on a channel with tons of commercials, you just MUST leave it on and see it again and after you do, you just feel good! Yeah, one of "those".It's a truly wonderful picture. Peck and Audrey and Eddie Albert and all of the supporting cast are terrific.This last viewing, I noticed the hair stylist more than I ever had before and found Ann's reaction to his admiration of her just so... sooo ... well, watch it and you'll see what I mean.All in all, it's deserving of its "classic status" and a "must see"...many times !

reviews.review_title: Dissapointing, And With Little Chemistry Between Hepburn And Peck
reviews.content: I watched Roman Holiday on a DVD that was bundled with Sabrina and Breakfast at Tiffanys. (Which are two other Hepburn films.) It proved to be the most dissapointing of the three. Which is too bad, as the story had potential, and was filmed on location in Rome, Italy. Their were a number of issues, which interfered with my enjoyment of it. Firstly, the lack of chemistry between Peck and Hepburn. We have to wait until near the end, when they kiss, before we finally feel the romance. Secondly, Eddie Albert is annoying and his acting sucks. Thirdly, it fails to show the city of Rome in an intimate way. (Was that now why it was filmed there?) All we get are some scenes with famous locations serving as a backdrop. Fourthly, the ending is schmaltzy with a capital S, and drawn out to the point that you will start twiddling the convertor.

My first acquaintance with Audrey Hepburn, Gregory Peck and basically old black and white movies has been exactly like a love from a first sight: immediate and deep to the core. The lightness of the situations and comedic touch amaze from the moment you meet the characters. As an experienced cinema lover, I should probably be thick-skinned and impervious to the little visual jokes but here the warmth and childish manner of the exposition melts my cold heart and gives clumsy sweet giggles.As soon as I saw Gregory Peck I knew that this is a real kind of man in front of me. Truly, the first impression knocks a person from own sneakers with looks and demeanor that represent an utmost gentleman. Although deeper into the story you'll get to see the sneaky-snake alter ego of a reporter the affection to him will always be there.The picture brings us to Rome and as a skilled tour guide for a day shows marvelous places of the city that wake the spirit of adventure and force you to book tickets straight away. It is still unbelievable how so many events are put all the way through the plot without the feeling of being cramped together.I could go on for hours but I should just say that the movie left me the pest of possible memories, unspoiled and genuinely romantic. For what it's worth I recommend to watch it as soon as two free hours pop into your tight schedule.

reviews.review_title: This is a great romantic film actually set in Rome of 1953
reviews.content: William Wyler gets a great performance out of Gregory and Audrey. And the film received more than its share of awards. There are more than the average number of comments re this film.I saw this film in the theaters shortly after it came out, and was captivated by it. However, I recently watched it on TCM and thoroughly enjoyed it again.But...I could not watch it this time without wondering about some practical considerations. Dalton Trumbo is a great writer, despite his erroneous political beliefs. Was it Trumbo who created this fantasy about Audrey being a Princess from an Eastern European Country. Come on Dalton, all of Eastern Europe was under Joe Stalins's dictatorship in 1953. What remained of the Central and Eastern monarchies after WWI, was completely demolished by Stalin and the Communists. Isn't that what their revolution was about.Trumbo's dialog in the first minutes of the film makes it quite clear, that Audrey who in real life was born in Holland, is an Eastern European Princesses whose mission is tie her imaginary Eastern Monarchy with Western Europe. I began to wonder if Trumbo was trying to exonerate himself from his pro-red tag, by writing this endearing film that is a fantasy. In the last scene of the film I couldn't help but laugh at the "polite" press corps. I doubt whether there would have been many at Audrey's press briefing, but if there was an interest in her, the press would have not been as polite as shown. In reality, there would have been a mob scene as reporters and especially photographers grappled with each other.For those who find my observations picky, I apologize. This film is great despite my observations because it is an implausible love story that is credible with my above noted exceptions. The Roman background of post war Rome was a reminder to those who watched this film originally, that Europe was finally getting out from under the ruble of WWII. This is a wonderful love story without naked bodies doing all sorts of things that were better off left to our own wicked imaginations. This film lives on, as we forget the semi-pornographic films that have replaced gems such as Roman Holiday.

saw that film in 1953..loved it tremendously and was infatuated by Audrey Hepburn went to work in Rome in 1954 because of that movie...now in 2006 saw the movie again and saw so many flaw..vert slow dialogue..childish behaviour and minimal acting..what's left Audrey Hepburn only ..gregory peck stodgy and Eddie Albert specially is obnoxious and aggravating...what annoyes me the most were the Italian actors playing such sterotype of what American see the italians...quite dreadful....Williamm Wyler such a great director does not come off well in this in 2006..at the time it was a travelogue for Italy..specially after the war years film like roman holiday and three coins in the fountain showed America what Italy was.....so far for me the film is a total miss ib 2006,,, and will never watch it again..should have reserved my first opinion and stayed with that...please let me know if anybody thinks like i do ...michel from MONTREAL
Such a great movie, beautiful plot & so aesthetic!

I just don't get it how such movies get so many good reviews and even win Oscars! Now again, what's so good about this movie?! Don't bother answering, I know: Nothing! Boring story with no memorable lines and nothing about it is entertaining. I like Gregory Peck and Hepburn though but the movie just fails to do it for me.I think people just like fairy tales put for them in a realistic mold. I don't mind stories of the like but if were entertaining and can make me bear to the end.I have to say though that I can totally understand those movies were good in their own times being new ideas and when there was like one actor every 20 years but not nowadays, oh nah!

reviews.review_title: Hepburn Still Magical A Half Century Later In Reverse Cinderella Story
reviews.content: This is still the quintessential Audrey Hepburn movie. If you think Angelina Jolie, Julia Roberts, and Kate Winslet are the essence of Hollywood beauty but have never seen Audrey Hepurn, you are missing out on one of the greatest of screen icons. Although there are wonderful actresses who have graced many-a Hollywood film, there is only one Audrey Hepburn. She may be the greatest Hollywood female icon of all time in terms of her combination of acting, demeanor, charm, intelligence and personality. There was always an innocently vulnerable, adolescent quality to Audrey Hepburn, even when she was much older. Simultaneously, she had this spunky mischievous side to her that shines through in "Roman Holiday"--innocent curiosity that has been immortalized in the two decades she graced the large screen. And of course she was one of the most enduringly beautiful women in the history of film. "Roman Holiday" is Hepburn doing what she does best.The premise of "Roman Holiday" is a bit of a Hollywood contrivance, but the dialog and the acting save it from becoming corny. It is Cinderella in reverse. The essential plot concerns Audrey Hepburn as a royal princess from a "nameless" European country. (Even one supporting character reaffirms that the country will remain nameless.) She is bored with her overly protected life which is so highly structured and ceremonial that even when she inadvertently loses her shoe during a high-class engagement, retrieving it becomes an act of refined etiquette. She is in Rome, one stop on a European tour with her entourage of dignitaries, and residing at her country's embassy. Anxious to leave, if only for a moment, the gilded cage of her life of royal obligation, she sneaks out of the embassy and enters the heart of Rome via a food truck.Later she ends up drunk and unconscious on a Roman sidewalk. And guess who should happen by but Gregory Peck as Joe Bradley, second-rate American reporter who would like nothing more than to get the scoop of the century and hop back to the New York press scene. But of course he doesn't know who she is. Being a relatively good Samaritan, he rescues her from the streets and brings her into his studio apartment. All the while it is unbeknown-st to him that she is the princess who is having a press conference the following morning in which he is scheduled to attend for his newspaper. Despite the fact that she is still the epitome of ultimate cuteness (young women like Hepburn always look the cutest when they're sleeping), he dumps her on his couch while she is still amidst her drunken stupor. The next morning, however, his feelings toward her do a 180 when he realizes who she really is. It would be a great story, worth $5000, for a reporter whose career has stagnated to get an exclusive interview with the princess. And he solicits friend and press photographer Irving (Eddie Albert) for pictures to prove the story. At first the movie is a kind of madcap scheme to get the story at all costs. Some of the funniest moments are when Albert meets Hepburn and Peck at a café and Peck has to figure out a way to tell his colleague about the circumstances without letting on to naive Hepburn. But then the story begins to develop into something else as the relationship between Hepburn and Peck evolves into something deeper. And the ending of the movie is bitter-sweet saving the story from becoming pure sap.There is no question that this movie is rather schmaltzy by 21st-century standards. The story is a fantasy-comedy, but the writing and the acting which never lapses into too much sentimentality save the film, which could have been much sillier and much more syrupy. The sobering ending makes the film much better than it could have been. And of course Audrey Hepburn who essentially made her major screen debut steals the show. Best to see this one with your significant other and some clean-ex.

reviews.review_title: Audrey's first major role and one of her best
reviews.content: I saw this movie when I was 18 and it took me more than once to really enjoy it. Now that I've seen it again (I've watched it four times) I love it. Audrey Hepburn was just coming into her prime (and won herself a much-deserved Oscar), Gregory Peck was the perfect guy to play her leading man, and Eddie Albert is an ideal second banana. It's too bad that Audrey is no longer with us today but at least she's left us her remarkable heritage of films, books and photos to remember her and the formidable mark she's left on the motion picture industry. Here's to Audrey and her remarkable career!!!

I loved this movie. It was romantic, and there were some excellent 'drop dead funny' parts. By the end of this movie, you'lll probably want to just pack up your bags, buy a ticket to Italy, and get a motor scooter. The only part of this movie I did not like, though, was the ending. Some people thought that it would be too much of a fantasy, and too unbelieveable of a movie if Gregory Peck actually got to stay with Audrey Hepburn. But that's the ending that most people expected. I sure didn't think that the end would be that bittersweet. Actually, I ended up throwing my empty tissue box at the television set and yelling at Peck to turn right around and run into Hepburn's arms. But, of course, he didn't. What else can I say? Audrey was fantastic, as usual. She was graceful, witty, goregeous, and most of all, charming. Gregory Peck was delightful, sneaky, and pretty handsome. I adored this movie. It is a must see. Iwould just go right out and buy it if you are an old romantic or just love Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck's acting!

The plot of Roman holiday is simple, but it has become a world classic by virtue of the successful performance of the protagonist and the Roman street scenery. The lovely hairstyle of Hepburn will be forever. The film vividly melts the famous scenery of Rome into the plot, and makes a romantic love comedy very warm and pleasing to the eyes. Two people are bored with the tedious courtly rituals, one is a small reporter in his pocket. One day in Rome, though short, is a relaxing time for them to experience the sweet love. Although in the end they did not come together because of their respective identities and responsibilities, Rome became a symbol of their permanent love. The film also describes a romantic and pure love in a fairy tale like story. Although their love has no result, it does not make people sad. On the contrary, their love is warm and unique. Innocent and mischievous Princess and kind and scheming reporter, their love is destined to be a beautiful imagination in the age of innocence.
That's the best movie I have seen since "swing time" and I love it! Completely distracting ! You should watch it :))

reviews.review_title: A Fun Romp, as the Kids Say
reviews.content: A bored and sheltered princess (Audrey Hepburn) escapes her guardians and falls in love with an American newsman (Gregory Peck) in Rome.This film is fun, has two very charismatic actors, and set an archetype for many similar films in the years to come. Some, such as "Chasing Liberty", almost blatantly ripping off the story without any credit given... and then there are nice subtle homages, such as seen in "The Little Mermaid".What confuses me about this film is how it got Audrey Hepburn her Oscar. My best guess, based on looking at the other contenders, is that she did not have much competition. I really found nothing outstanding about her performance -- she is much more remarkable in "My Fair Lady" or "Wait Until Dark".

The film vividly blends the sights of Rome into the plot, and makes a romantic love comedy very warm and pleasing. Two people are bored with the boring and trivial court courtesy, and one is a shy little reporter in the bag. Although the day in Rome is short, the relaxing time makes them feel the sweetness of love. Although in the end they did not come together because of their respective identities and responsibilities, Rome became a symbol of their permanent love

reviews.review_title: unbeatable: two for the price of one - audrey + rome
reviews.content: i love movies shot on location COMPLETELY. no half halfs here. of course, if you read trivia you would know the real reasons. but for me, a story of love in rome just isn't the same, filmed anywhere else.actually, it's 3 for the price of one. you get a handsome Mr Peck too. but since im a guy, that don't work for me. its just audrey and rome all the way. of course, rome today is not the same rome. that's why i treasure this movie all the more.my fave scenes are, in order of preference: 1) the end 2) the mouth of truth (go read the trivia on this scene, but only after having watched it first) 3) the escape swim and afterwards

Roman Holiday is excellent without a doubt!!! Instead of having the true fairy tale ending it gave us a bit of reality. I was disappointed with it at first, but then realized that not all life ends like a fairy tale. This movie showed me that. Both people made sacrifices for who they loved. It was a true romance and comedy driven film. When I saw it I never knew how funny it really was and at the same time is a drama and romance. I watched this movie with my mom and grandma, it is a film for all ages. My mom reminisces about when she first say it and how she loved it and still loves it. Gregory Peck is one of my favorite actors, he will always be. He was great in To kill a Mockingbird, which was the first movie I saw with him in it and I just adored him and his acting since. I know I sound old writing this, but I am not. I just love to watch old films and I love to see the old actors. Acting is fun and they are more of role models for me than some of the actors out now today. I think that watching older films is something my family and I can do together, so I guess that is why I like them so much. As a child you do not really appreciate old films until you get a little older and that is how it was with me. Well, any ways this is one of the greatest films I have seen all year and of all time!!! I think that everyone should see this movie!!! I truly think it is one of the greatest out there!!! The acting is awesome!!! So everyone go see it and have a good time when you watch it!!!

In Italy for a goodwill tour, pretty European princess Audrey Hepburn (as Ann) is bored meeting foreign dignitaries. Her royal highness doesn't like wearing old-fashioned underwear and retiring early with a glass of milk and crackers. She wants to go out and party. After Ms. Hepburn is given a sleep-inducing injection, she goes out and falls asleep on the streets of Rome. Down-on-his-luck New York newspaperman Gregory Peck (as Joe Bradley) finds Hepburn and, thinking she's a drunk, takes her home to sober up. When the morning papers feature Hepburn's picture, Mr. Peck smells a story...But love gets in the way...This flat soufflé is worth watching for the credits - especially Hepburn, in her first big role. She is thoroughly charming, and everyone could see a star was born. The story of a royal coming down to earth to mingle with mere mortals goes back to the silent days and will likely continue as long as there are "royals". Other than seeing Hepburn pass the star test, there are some artful moments. The scene where Hepburn and Peck put their hands in "the mouth of truth" statue is an instance where the locale and personnel come alive. Photographer Eddie Albert (as Irving Radovich) supports Peck well.******* Roman Holiday (8/27/53) William Wyler ~ Audrey Hepburn, Gregory Peck, Eddie Albert, Paolo Carlini

If you have any sort of cheap romantic side to you then you are going to love this. Audrey is simply beautiful, Rome looks stunning, Gregory Peck is pretty slick and solid in a sort of Cary Grantish way. It even manages to communicate quite a bit of sexual energy which, given that when it was made naked flesh was very much a no-go area, shows that romance can be just as powerful as raw sex appeal.You could worry that it isn't very deep, it doesn't really try to break new ground and that the ending is a bit empty. However, as Ron Manager might have said, the lads give their all and at the end of the ninety minutes clichés can be pretty good fun.

SPOILERS Often one of the most annoying aspects of Hollywood is the way that certain films are used purely to promote an area. Spending the entire film travelling around one particular location, the film can become disjointed as the story is sacrificed in favour of simply showing the sights. Luckily though, "Roman Holiday" never succumbs to this problem. Travelling around Rome, the film might include major areas of Rome's history, but never at the expense of the love story between Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn. Working well together, the two leads make this story a beautiful tale of love and happiness.Audrey Hepburn plays Princess Ann. As a member of a royal house, she faces countless chore like duties. One night however, she sneaks away with the intention of truly experiencing life. Being found by journalist Joe Bradley (Peck), she is shown the sights of Rome as Bradley helps her to achieve all of the dreams she'd always wished for.Despite sounding like an unlikely partnership, the way Hepburn and Peck work together on this film is breathtaking. Winning an Oscar for her performance, Hepburn thrills as the innocent princess who learns about life and love all in a day. Peck by the same accord is equally superb with his eye on a story, and the money it'll bring. Showing the changes in the two characters as they spend time together, the two leads are wonderful. Unfortunately because the film was released in the same year as "From Here To Eternity" and "Julius Caesar", Peck never even received an Oscar nomination for his performance. This might seem unfair considering most other years he would be probably looking at actually winning the award itself.With some wonderful jokes, and some amazing moments, "Roman Holiday" never ceases to thrill. Hepburn deservedly won the Best Actress Oscar for this role, and it was this which made her a star. Teaming up with Gregory Peck, she thrives as the two produce one of the most beautiful romantic stories ever told. Two fine performances, amazing scenery and a great plot, make this one holiday to remember forever.

"Hit him again, Smithy!"For the last few years, it's become a Valentine's Day tradition for me to watch Roman Holiday. This year it came a day late, but I've enjoyed it more with each viewing.I don't know which I like more: the acting or the writing. The two leads are played flawlessly by Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck, two of my all-time favorites. Hepburn is charming as always and Peck is as classy as ever.In this viewing, I paid more attention to the writing and dialogue, and some of the comedy is pure genius. The ending is different from the rest of the movie and is done in a different tone. It's not funny, yet not sad. It's not satisfying, yet not disappointing. I feel like everyone in the audience can relate to Peck, slowly walking down the Sala Grande Galleria, lost in his thoughts of what could have been. Cue the end credits.This is just one of those rare timeless love stories that I will forever consider one of my favorites. Guaranteed to enjoy.

I don't know why I'm writing this review, there are already tons of glowing reviews of this film. Mine just makes one more. I just want to comment briefly on the three big stars of the film:o Audrey HepburnHere-to-fore, I'd liked Hepburn, but never been particularly a fan. This film made me a fan. She was just *perfect* for the role, I can't imagine it being done by anyone else.o Gregory PeckIt is well known that Cary Grant was originally offered the part, and I'm a huge Cary Grant fan, and consider him my favorite actor. But hands down, Peck was the right man for this role. He has a great chemistry with Hepburn that I don't think Cary could've pulled off.o RomeRome is absolutely delicious in this film. Just a couple years ago, I had a wonderful vacation in Rome, and watching this film brought it all back for me. Scene after scene after scene, I was going "I was there!" or "I know that place!" Rome is a wonderful city, and the decision to film entirely on location there really puts the movie over the top.Finally, for those who wonder what country Audrey was the princess of, well, while the movie never explicitly states it, the answer is obvious: Freedonia.

Roman Holiday (1953): Dir: William Wyler / Cast: Audrey Hepburn, Gregory Peck, Eddie Albert, Hartley Power, Harcourt Williams: Engaging romantic comedy about adventures beyond our usual psyche. Audrey Hepburn plays a Princess who is bored with the meaningless schedules and wishes to partake in normal activities. Seizing the opportunity she runs away one evening but is discovered by a reporter, played by Gregory Peck who mistakes her for a drunken teenager. When newspapers announce that the Princess is ill as a cover-up, Peck realizes who his guest is and participates sight seeing about Rome while his photographer sneaks snapshots. Beautiful film full of hilarious situations and an ending worth applauding. Director William Wyler previously made Mrs. Miniver. Here he highlights normality and showcases exquisite Rome. Hepburn is hilarious in her innocence while Peck is wonderful as the scheming reporter overcome by guilt. Eddie Albert makes a great foil as Peck's willing photographer. In limited supporting roles Hartley Power plays his editor who engages in a bet and never fully realizes how far ahead he truly was. Other roles are rather one dimensional but viewers will be likely focused on Hepburn's radiant energy. One of the greatest of romantic comedies. It celebrates normality while honesty makes this just about the best holiday ever filmed. Score: 9 ½ / 10

In my opinion, this is truly the most perfect movie! The casting director was absolutely brilliant with involving Gregory Peck (who is a personal favourite actor of mine) as well with Audrey Hepburn and Eddie Albert.
All of the actors had wonderful and entertaining chemistry that really helped carry the movie. The mixture of forbidden romance and comedy was a brilliant twist that you wouldn't normally see in a movie. This is the best performance of Hepburn and one of the many great performances of Peck. (All my respect to Gregory Peck with telling the company to move Audrey Hepburn's name next to him!! Seems like a pathetic notion but for the time period and the fact that this was Audrey's first film? was marvelous!)
The fact that they also filmed the entire movie in Italy is another factor that I love so much!
Can't get better than that! (other than the fact that they should have ended together but is understandable why they aren't...but still!)

William Wyler directed this charming comedy that stars Audrey Hepburn(who won an Academy Award for best actress) as Princess Ann, who is touring European countries and while in Rome, gets bored with the routine so impulsively sneaks out on her entourage and slips into a truck, and later falls asleep on a park bench, where she is found by American journalist Joe Bradley(played by Gregory Peck) who later finds out her true identity, and decides to befriend her by giving her a tour of the sights and landmarks, while trying to not fall in love with the lovely young woman... Popular film works as both comedy and romance, handling both with believability and care. A slight film to be sure, but most appealing.

reviews.review_title: My angry review of Roman Holiday
reviews.content: I'm sorry, fans of Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck, but I hated this film.More specifically, I'm not a fan of the lead actress, and that's why I started my review with an apology. Audrey Hepburn, as other people have pointed out, was basically the Julia Roberts of her day. Looked alright, wore nice hats, had what people would consider good fashions (although if I want good fashions, I'll watch a film from the 1930s or 1940s), and couldn't act her way out of a paper bag with a blowtorch. Also, both had (have) rather large mouths with what appear to be four dozen teeth in them. Audrey Hepburn is shoved so far down the throats of us classic film fans that I just don't know how people still like her. Or Bette Davis. Or Liz Taylor. Or Marilyn Monroe. Or Grace Kelly. Or Ingrid Bergman. Or Katharine Hepburn.Okay, I'll stop before people start throwing things at me.I haven't seen enough of Gregory Peck to decide if I like him or not. He was quite good looking in the 1940s, in that real Henry Fonda-esque 'teacher fresh out of college' way. He was terrible in this film, so I don't know how I think of him as an actor. Maybe it was his female lead. Eddie Albert I like, although I may be biased towards him because Green Acres is the only TV show I can watch full episodes of.The plots lifts quite a lot from It Happened One Night- as it may have been pointed out. Of course, they changed the main female character from a heiress to a princess, changed the locale from the USA to Rome, changed the ending so the two leads don't end up together (the only good part of this film) , took out the famous hitchhiking scene and replaced it with a brawl at a party, and crammed the adventures of the two leads into a day.It doesn't work. The ending change just screwed things over. Speaking of screwed, It Happened One Night was a screwball comedy. Because screwball was a dead genre by 1945, they slowed the dialogue down so that 1953 audiences could understand. It doesn't work.How the heck did Audrey Hepburn win an Oscar for this film? Were there no other good female performances in the year 1953? Okay, so it was the year of Torch Song (compared to that film, Roman Holiday is the greatest picture ever made), but there were other good female performances. I think.So, I'm in the minority, but I'm going to say that unless you have nothing better to do and you really, really want to watch this film, go ahead. But watch It Happened One Night after. And maybe The Princess Comes Across, if you feel like it.You might like this film: I did not.

reviews.review_title: Roman Holiday is why we love movies
reviews.content: Movies, the most contrived of the popular arts, can also have the most emotional power of those arts when then work. And Roman Holiday works. It's simply a magical combination of diverse and unreproducible elements that came together one magical summer in Rome.Audrey Hepburn, a young beautiful, multilingual war refugee was just catching the attention of the film world after abandoning a dance career. Everything in her background made her the ideal modern day princess.Gregory Peck, having established himself as the first great postwar leading man, in the mold of Jimmy Stewart, Clark Cable and Gary Cooper, was looking to demonstrate his comic chops and loved the script.William Wyler, a deft and non doctrinaire director, believed the character's emotional journeys and not his own psychological demons made a memorable film. He was no less an auteur for this, he just knew how to get the hell out of the way.Money! The studio had enough of it tied up by tax laws overseas that it didn't wish to repatriate it under Obama's( oops...Truman's) high tax rates. The solution...shoot a film in Rome with the loot.Rome....By all mean Rome...in glorious, sharp Black and White which allows tremendous depth of field in each frame. No fuzzy close-ups here. In almost every frame Rome is the co-star un-nominated for an Oscar.History. Europe was divided, in ruins, and yet still the wellspring of the American mind and soul. And there were two young princesses in England, one dating a commoner, that provided a real world context to the fantasy we enjoy on screen.Spoiler Alert. Finally, it is a romantic comedy about loss. The boy does not get the girl because she chooses duty over love. We love many during our lives, and lose most. Roman Holiday does not gloss over this, but shows why, in the end, we can never not take the trip.

reviews.review_title: They don't make films like these anymore.
reviews.content: I had the chance to watch Roman Holiday on the big screen at a local old fashioned theater.  I must say that I'm glad that I took that chance. Seeing the film on the big screen with people around was amazing.  This film is so charming and funny that it doesn't compare to the romantic comedies we get these days.  Audrey Hepburn is wonderful and no one can ever replace her.  Gregory Peck is just as wonderful.  If you ever have the chance to this movie in a theater, take it.  Belive me, you won't regret it!

A delightful romantic comedy starring Gregory Peck, Audrey Hepburn in her breakthrough role and the city of Rome as third lead. I've visited that wonderful city three or four times and can readily appreciate its being termed the Eternal City, it's so full of remarkable, historic buildings and monuments, so that even today many of these famous sites still look the same as they did then.The story seems recycled from Capra's "It Happened One Night", as a scoop-seeking news-hound, Peck, bumps into Hepburn's frustrated, pent-up Princess Anne character, just after she's bunked off her royal duties to get out and see the real Rome.In her ensuing twenty four hours of freedom, with Peck and his long-suffering and frequently soaking wet photographer Eddie Albert as her guides, the young princess first crops her hair but in every other respect, lets her hair down for a night of fun, frivolity and music.For me, the only wrong note was the improbable instantly-flowering romance between the plainly much older Peck and the young Hepburn, but compensations abound elsewhere not only in the fine cinematography capturing Rome in its glory but also the witty script, stylish direction by Wyler, not forgetting the warm and attractive acting by the two leads.It's rare to see a film of this type so deftly balance the mixture of romance and comedy as maestro Wyler achieves here. All I know is that seeing this film again and remembering that my last time there I duly threw my coin in the Trevi Fountain, I'm reassured that I will visit the city again at sometime in the future.

SPOILERS!  BEWARE!"Roman Holiday" was a delightful little movie.  It has a warmth and sweetness that still hold power 50 years after it's creation.  At the same time, it's not exactly "Pollyana" either.  Key moments are when the "naive little princess" smokes her first cigarette, drinks wine, sleeps (in the same room) with a complete stranger, passes out in the street, and gets in a brawl.  This is truly the stuff of exploration and is still convincing today.  Probably one of "Roman Holiday's" most significant aspects is its surprisingly narrow scope.  Despite its grand, cosmopolitan locale, "Roman Holiday" encompasses about a day and a half and its plot is basically what would've constituted one chapter in Tom Sawyer.  (Protagonist climbs out of room under the cover of darkness, sees the sights, meets some interesting people, and then goes back home).  This myopic focus is an important part of "Roman Holiday's" charm but also probably keeps it from being a perfect film.Obviously, Audrey Hepburn, is a delight to watch.  She manages to simultaneously be feminine and boyish, elegant and common, and flighty but grounded.  Of course, these are characteristics that not only perfectly represented Princess Ann but remain a key element in Hepburn's acting whatever her role.  Gregory Peck was good too.  Some criticize the lack of chemistry between the two.  I agree that things are a bit wooden romantically but their initial spark of interest coupled with fundamental incompatibility is a key part of the story (as it is in "Random Hearts" with Harrison Ford and Kristin Scott Thomas).  Finally, I really admired the "walk away" ending.  Sure, it stung a little but it made sense and it was beautifully done as Peck walked through that elegant, cavernous room.  It was good to remember that serendipitous "love" doesn't need sex or even marriage to validate it.  Like the fleeting friendships established in "The Breakfast Club" some things, however special, aren't meant to last.  That's part of what makes them so special. The film's charm is a sense of summer after highschool when days are a bit lazier, nights a bit longer and everything a bit more possible, briefly the horizon is pushed back and new things pop up, become suddenly possible for someone who is no longer a kid and not yet an adult, so the charm hasn't worn off. He is a cynical journalist, but we only need to be able to see the storyteller who (along with his photographer friend who captures images of this) creates the cinematic framework that reveals inner life. Princess Ann alludes to the Cinderella story by saying, "And at midnight I'll turn into a pumpkin and drive away in my glass slipper," which, of course, mixes up the elements of the fairytale. In similar way, the movie itself is a Cinderella story with the elements mixed up.Cinderella was a lady by birth, but forced into servitude by her wicked stepmother. For one night, she is able to dress up like the lady she really is. Princess Ann is a commoner by nature, and for one day she is able to dress up like the ordinary person she really is. At the end of the fairytale, Cinderella comfortably slides her foot into a glass slipper; at the beginning of the movie, Ann slides her foot out of the shoe that is bothering her. Cinderella marries the Prince she has fallen in love with; Ann does not marry the commoner she has fallen in love with.We expect there to be a moment when she finds out that Joe is a reporter, causing her to feel hurt and betrayed, believing that he tricked her for the sake of a story; and that he will say that was true at first, but now he is in love with her; and then she will say she does not believe him, and so on. That is the formula for movies when there is deception about someone's identity. In "The Prisoner of Zenda" (1952), for example, when Princess Flavia finds out that the man she fell in love with is just an impostor, she jumps to the conclusion that his courting her was part of the act, and thus she feels betrayed. In "Roman Holiday," however, it is refreshing that Ann trusts Joe so much that one brief assurance from him is all she needs.As with Princess Flavia, Princess Ann gives up the man she loves for the sake of her royal duties, but we have to wonder why. "The Prisoner of Zenda" was written in 1894, back when monarchs still mattered. And in the movie, much is made of the danger of letting someone like Michael seize the throne. But by 1953, monarchs had pretty much become ceremonial, kept around as tourist attractions. After all, when King Edward VIII of England abdicated his throne to marry Wallis Simpson, civil war did not break out, so it is hard to believe that Princess Ann could not abdicate without precipitating some kind of political disaster.In fact, I have my suspicions about King Edward VIII. The story is that he loved Wallis Simpson so much that he made the great sacrifice of giving up his throne for her. But I think he was just using her as an excuse. The idea of being a titular monarch, with no power but lots of ceremonial duties, might have been maddeningly tedious to him, and he was glad to get out of it. Just to say, "I don't want to be King, because it's boring," would have been a great insult. But everyone understands that love conquers all, and with that as a cover story, he made his escape.And this brings us back to Princess Ann. She clearly hated her duties, and she loved Joe. How nice it would have been, when Joe indicates that he will not publish what happened between them in the newspaper, for her to immediately renounce her position, and say she intends to marry him, the two of them walking away together to live happily ever after. As it is, we sort of feel that the boring life she has resigned herself to is just what she deserves.

We added this movie to the VintageIreland Film Club for the week of Valentine's Day because it's a standout romantic comedy.Swooning maidens and swelling music are all very well, but this film has something more important to say about love, relationships and falling in love. Despite its wildly unrealistic dressing, the central idea that relationships have value even when they can no longer continue (for whatever reason), and that their worth is directly derived from how much the people in that relationship value and respect one another, is a great deal more romantic and sincere than many of cinema's classic romances.Wonderful performances from both Hepburn and Peck certainly don't hurt either!
