Roman Holiday (1953), directed by William Wyler, was the first starring movie role for Audrey Hepburn. (The credits say, Gregory Peck and "Introducing Audrey Hepburn.") Hepburn, at 24, wasn't exactly an unknown, but her success in Roman Holiday changed the course of her career. Hepburn won an Oscar for her portrayal of Cinderella-in-reverse. She is Princess Ann, heir to the throne of an unnamed European nation. Cinderella dreams of becoming a princess; Princess Ann dreams of leading a normal life.Hepburn, having been given an injection to "quiet her nerves," wanders the streets of Rome, where she encounters newspaper reporter Joe Bradley, played by Gregory Peck. The next day, with Bradley and with photographer Irving Radovich (Eddie Albert) she sets out to enjoy one perfect, normal day.In 1953, Hepburn was at the height of her ingenue charm. She is breathtakingly beautiful in this film. With her strong elegant features, her lithe dancer's body, and her tiny waist, she dominates the screen in every scene in which she appears. Both Peck and Albert do their customary excellent work, and Rome looks wonderful and romantic.IMDb reviewers have ranked this film within the top 250 films of all time, and I would agree with them. It's not a masterpiece, but it's definitely worth seeking out and viewing. We saw Roman Holiday in the wonderful Dryden Theatre in George Eastman House, Rochester. It will work on a small screen, but seeing it in a theater is even better. Find it and enjoy it!

Warning do not read unless seen movie.I always love going on holiday. There always special to me not just in simply getting to relieve tension but they always give you a sense of clarity, from seeing and experiencing things realizes theirs more to life outside our familiar surroundings but also makes you realize where else you want to go and what more you want to be in life.This is one of the other romance films I really like, I'm not a fan of the genre per say it's not really my genre, but I do like some of them when their done right and this is one of them. It's true this is a romance that takes place in only about one day's time which makes this a little unlikely. But what makes this endearing is the fact that both characters are genuinely interacting.There is just a lot to like about this film, from the music which is very good. The cinematography and the use of the Rome locale, even though this film was a long time ago the scenes of certain locales of Rome are still beautiful to look at. It sorts of makes the film a lot more interesting almost a photography/cinematography history lesion as it's all shot in black and white. The use of them also in a way reflects the romance between both the leads which just says adventurous and beautiful.But of course, what really drives this film are the two main leads.Gregory Peck is great as John Bradley he's a reporter that is kind of on the underdog side of things as he's a bit washed out from his fame along with his carrier which is common with most star reporters. I really like his sense of integrity and that he's not a stereotypical egocentric reporter. At first in the film it almost seems like he's going to fast track back to fame by exploiting Anya which is tempting but unethical all the same. But we see he decides not to do that as he's gets to know her a lot more and as we see fall for her. I really like how he has this dry charisma and humor to him which makes him a likeable guy.And of course, Aubrey Hepburn herself, this film of course was her film debut and it really was the one the started it all for her. I really like this actress, I'll admit I had a bit of a crush on her when I was a kid, she is just beautiful inside and out. Just has this radiance of loveliness, it was just in the looks but her voice and persona that just has this draw. Aubrey in a way was sort of playing herself in the film as she puts on her usual lovely sweet classy charisma but also sharp humor.I really love her character Princess Ann, she's a really sympathic character when we see at the beginning, she is just kind of in a psychological funk despite not showing it, she is keeping hidden as best she can with her royalty mask but as we see there are cracks forming. She is bored, lonely, no one really treats her like a person more like how someone would maintain a nice classic car. Just seeing that makes me wonder about the lives of certain celebrities out their or other famous figures, it just goes to show that fame and fortune aren't all it's cracked up to be.So does what any sane person should do to save their sanity, go on Holiday, and I thought "way to go dudete" that's what I always do whenever I feel my stress levels are off the charts or I'm feeling like crap, why the heck not and as an old saying goes "a man's got to do, what a man's got to do" or should I say woman. Her journey throughout Rome to me wasn't just a fun getaway for her but kind of a coming of age tale for her. As she's a person that wants to be independent that wants to be treated as a person and liked for who she is not because she wears a crown.There is humor, and it's done right and hits at all the right spots. In most romances whenever humor is included I most of the time cringe more than laugh, because most of the situations the chacters are in are just so fraking ridiculous it's not even funny but worst of all it's also too much of a distraction for the characters to properly interact.The humor in this film is done right because during those times both characters are properly interacting and really, we're having a good time, but also we're funny and memorable. There are lots of funny and memorable moments, I'll just say a few of my favorites I don't' want to give too much away.Really like that fight at the dance with those secret government agents intrude, though they aren't very good ones, yeah like no one's going to notice the clichéd black trench coat and hat look. Ok it's not a great fight but I just thought it was fun and funny as we see Ann, John and Irving (Eddie Albert) were all getting in on the action. I always thought this scene shows John has guts, he's doing what any good boyfriend should do though likewise for Ann doing what any good girlfriend should do.The other is of course when both first met and of course he doesn't really know it's Anya, he mistakenly thinks she some random girl that's doped up which Anya was, but it was a sedative. It's just funny how Aubrey plays a person under sedation, though even in that state she's still lovely and sweet.Though my absolute favorite is the mouth of truth scene, it was both funny and suspenseful as we see both are tempting fate. Audrey's reaction was just priceless, and I couldn't help but crack up, and believe it or not that reaction actually was genuine it wasn't scripted.But it's really those sweet interactive moments I really loved when both truly to interact with one another, there are a lot of good pieces of dialog. You can see both are good for each other as he really draws out a more adventurous and slightly aggressive quality in Ann. While Ann draws out certain feelings, he let himself close himself of from but is now experiencing again.The dynamic between both is interesting, as it's one between one that has almost everlasting fame to another that was formerly famous but also just someone that has more experience in the world to another that has hardly begun to experience the world. My favorite moment in the interacting which I thought was really bitter sweet was when both of them kiss for the first and last time, when she says "I don't know how to say good bye" it's almost kind of heartbreaking because just like the whole adventure throughout the movie you wish it didn't have to end, you really wish both of them had more time together but like all holiday's it's has to end sooner or later.The only problem I have with the film is the ending, it just felt like there was something more that needed to be there. Personally, I would of liked it if both main characters had at least one final private conversation or something. I don't know that's just how I feel, it's a minor quibble.But as I said the film is bittersweet because we know even before the end that despite the good time both have spent together, their both not meant to be. I feel that's a reality that most of us face whenever we have some sort of relationship with someone, mainly because we're going different directions, lack of commonalities, just any kind of factor that can set people apart. Yet despite this you never forget the feelings you felt for one another and despite how far apart you are, those feelings stay with you because that person is never far from your thoughts.As Sarah Connor put it "even though we didn't have much time together, we loved a lifetimes worth."Rating: 4 stars

An overprotected princess travels to Rome, where she befriends an American journalist ... that's the story told in William Wyler's Roman Holiday (1953), a romantic comedy classic starring Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn.It is a tender story that is about the desire you have to find the person who you really are, your desire to get out of social pressures and be yourself. It is narrated in a linear fashion and we see how the characters evolve throughout history, learn through everything they live.The story is simple and flows through the personality of the characters, how they react to the situations they face. We see the characters astonished to do things for the first time, go through changes to start over, trying to be someone else for people to accept them for who they really are ... all to finally build confidence and trust.It's a movie that offers a glimpse into the life of a person "lucky" by his social position, which apparently seem more extraordinary and simple for the luxuries and comforts, but despite that fails to be happy and admire the grandeur of the life "common", is surprised by what others do may seem ordinary.While Wyler directs this classic with great performances of Hepburn and Peck, in this story that could be a rare version of "Cinderella" but that account so that the characters generate empathy with the viewer and make him spend some quality time.

" . . . it's always open season on princesses." So says photojournalist Irving (Eddie Albert) to homesick American reporter Joe (Gregory Peck) in reference to Princess Ann's (Audrey Hepburn's) 1953 ROMAN HOLIDAY. Ann's 24 hours of Wilding, comparable to an Amish youth's sowing their wild oats in "Rumspringa" season, has come to a bleak ending. Unlike the similarly-plotted "best picture" of 1934--Clark Gable and Claudette Colbert's IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT--there can be no "she lived happily ever after" close to ROMAN HOLIDAY. From the moment she was conceived, the possibility of casual "hook-ups" flew out the window, and now that Ann is newly hooked on cigarettes, the main question for her future is whether she will produce a properly-pedigreed heir before lung cancer claims her. Not that the world will suffer greatly from the loss of a few inbred Royals, or that such an excruciating demise would be preferable to sudden death by car crash, as was the case with Princess Diana of Wales and Princess Grace of Monaco. However, many historical cultures have had their "Royals" serve double duty as national scapegoats, validating Irving's "open season" remark. Not every film has the power to make an "ordinary Joe" give a hoot about a crowned head. This makes ROMAN HOLIDAY a rare triumph.

My first Audrey Hepburn film, and I'm in love already. She deservedly won an Oscar for her portrayal of the young Princess Ann, a girl who has spent her entire life living the proper life of royalty and finally escapes into the city to enjoy life as a civilian. Even if it's just for one day. Gregory Peck gives a charming and remarkably humorous performance as Joe Bradley, the reporter who stumbles upon Ann and brings her back to his place so he can get an exclusive story of the Princess on the town. The two of them take a trip through Rome for one day, seeing all of the beautiful sites and falling in love with one another. It's one of the most charming, adorable films I've ever seen with a beautiful romance in the center created expertly by Peck and Hepburn. She gives what is easily one of the best female performances I've seen. One of those films that makes you feel like you're falling in love, as you see these two people do the same, while seeing absolutely beautiful scenery. I hear it said all the time with the film, and I feel the same way; it makes me want to spend a day in Rome. The final scene is heartbreaking, but not in a devastating way that will leave you shaking on the floor. You know what's going to happen, but the chemistry between the two is so flawless that the film makes you beg for them to slip into unrealism just for a second.

reviews.review_title: Romantic feeling without a lot of contrivance
reviews.content: I own a copy of this film which I bought years ago, and I probably haven't viewed it since I first bought it...until tonight. And once while playing a home-made version of Scene It with some friends, I used the footage where she puts her hand in the wall. So that is the part of the movie I tend to remember most. But I did re-watch it in its entirely tonight on TCM. I have to be honest. It is wonderfully absorbing but it is a product of its time and definitely too slow for young modern audiences who may not have the patience to allow the story, or at least the relationship between the three main characters, to carefully unfold. It became very clear to me that ROMAN HOLIDAY's 119 minute running time could easily be whittled down to 95 or 100 minutes and it wouldn't hurt this picture at all. But then we might lose some of the deeper, meaningful pauses and the sightseeing tour of Rome that sort of exists within the movie. I suspect that if it had been made back in Hollywood on the Paramount back lot, there would have been less drawn-out sequences where the director is encouraging us to absorb and take in real Rome. And speaking of taking in the Roman sights, I think it was a mistake to have filmed it in black and white. They had young stars who did not need black-and-white photography to help conceal aging, and the beauty and splendor of the Roman culture would surely have looked much grander in Technicolor. I also think there should have been more local music and dialects in the background, like we see in BUONA SERA MRS. CAMPBELL or A ROOM WITH A VIEW. As it is, ROMAN HOLIDAY is too silent and quite frankly too un-Italian in some of its representations.Also, I think the picture seems unsure of itself in spots, trying to decide if it's a slapstick comedy or a romantic comedy. The repetitiveness of Eddie Albert getting splashed with beverages and falling down silly leaves one thinking that Wyler was absent on those days and the Marx Brothers had temporarily taken over directing.However, despite these slight gripes, the picture is still very effective in creating a mood. And it gives one reason to rejoice in the fact that a romantic feeling without a lot of contrivance or saccharine cuteness can be captured and sustained for much of a film's running time-- a rarity in most newer films.

Romantic comedies are just not my thing, a fact of life that continues to irritate my wife and probably always will.  Even so, I have to admit that Roman Holiday is a truly charming movie--worth every moment of screen time. It is infinitely better than most of the schlock that Hollywood bills as "romantic comedies" today, although this is hardly great praise.  The cast is completely effective, and the movie exudes a lingering sense of youth, longing, and romance that I felt for many an hour after I watched the film. It is also genuinely funny in a smart and even sexy--though thankfully not too sexy--way.  Everything about this movie charms.Even devoted enemies of so-called "romantic comedies" may find much to treasure here.

Given the accolades this film has received I was certainly expecting more. Gregory Peck once commented that every romantic comedy script he received had the fingerprints of Cary Grant on it. This transcends into the film itself. Peck is a marvelous actor, no doubt, but he lacks the kind of quirky charm that oozes from Grant. Take for example the scene in which Peck tries to take a camera from a young girl. Sure, the characters intentions are pure, but Peck came off as rather suspect. The film as a whole was simply too involved in the romance, to the point that it was obvious the route it would travel along. Hepburn is fantastic in her innocence, and there are many great moments, but after watching some other classics recently, this failed to engross me for its entire duration.

There's not a whole lot I can add to everyone's comments on this picture so far.  Audrey Hepburn is a marvel--I could watch her in just about anything. Having recently seen "Twelve O'Clock High", I'm also growing fond of Gregory Peck; the worst you can say about him in this movie is that he's no Clark Gable or Cary Grant, but then who is?  It's also a treat to see Eddie Albert in the pre-"Green Acres" days.  The Roman scenery is absolutely lovely, and it's interesting to compare this film with the Italian "neo-realist" films which were all the rage in the previous few years; one wonders if William Wyler saw, say, "Open City", and wondered what a Hollywood film crew could do with scenery like that?As for the plot, well...to be charitable, there's not a whole lot to it.  On the other hand, with Audrey Hepburn up there on the screen, who needs a plot?  With her, incident would seem to be sufficient.  Even though I personally prefer the more intricately worked storyline of "Sabrina", I understand why "Roman Holiday" could be considered the definitive Audrey Hepburn movie, why she won her only Oscar for it, and why it was the first of her films named to the National Film Registry.(SPOILER WARNING)  Nevertheless, there is one feature of interest in the story itself, especially considering that it was written by the blacklisted Dalton Trumbo, who'd been jailed as one of the "Hollywood Ten" who refused to cooperate with the House Un-American Activities Committee.  As Joe Bradley gets to know Princess Anne, she becomes more important to him as a person than as a story.  Just before letting her go back, he almost tells her who he really is, but she doesn't want to know.  (Does she already suspect that Joe might be too good to be true, and fears knowing for sure?) In that moment, Joe seems to realize that the best thing he can do for Anne is to keep silent about their "holiday", and this is confirmed by his subsequent actions.  In those days of "naming names", was Trumbo trying to send a message about the importance of keeping confidences?  (Compare the previous year's "High Noon", written by the soon-to-be-blacklisted Carl Foreman, on the importance of hanging together in the face of impending threat; contrast the following year's "On the Waterfront", written  by Budd Schulberg and directed by Elia Kazan [both friendly witnesses before HUAC], a justification of squealing.)Perhaps I've read too much into a film that has been a source of innocent enjoyment for several generations of filmgoers, and I hope I haven't spoiled that aspect of "Roman Holiday" for anyone.  Even so, I suspect the message about confidences may strike home below the conscious level for many viewers, which might explain why this film is an all-time favorite for so many.  (Besides Audrey Hepburn and its other naturally appealing elements, of course.)  It doesn't even have to have political significance, but only to reflect a wish for a world long gone.  Alas, in these days of information explosion, media time to be filled, and far too many people willing to sink to the lowest level to fill it, it is impossible to believe that such a "holiday" as Anne and Joe's would remain secret for long.

reviews.review_title: The movie that launched a legend.
reviews.content: Now this is a movie that I can never get enough of.  It could have something to do with the fact that I believe Audrey Hepburn to be the most elegant beauty to ever grace the silver screen, but I do believe that the movie stands on it's own merits as well.The pairing of Hepburn with Peck was perfect in the fact that their opposites play off each other.  Peck was charming and debonair, while Mrs. Hepburn was young and had that spark of innocence that just made you fall in love with her.  Together they turned a classic story idea into a fun movie that endears itself on your heart and in the process gave birth to the legend that is Audrey.

An American romantic comedy; Audrey Hepburn's Princess Ann, with her delightfully naïve sense of fun, was duly rewarded with an Academy Award. Her smile, as she awakens in a hack's apartment, charmed audiences the world over. Lissom beauty was matched by the tall, dark, and handsome Gregory Peck, who gave a graceful performance.

reviews.review_title: Everybody, Take A Holiday in Rome!!!!
reviews.content: You'll be falling in love with the most beautiful actress name Audrey Hepburn playing as the lovely Princess Ann falling in love with a handsome American newsman name Joe Bradley. It is a warm-hearted romantic comedy, and it is definitely one of the most beautiful and classic movies ever. It is impossible to not like this movie, because this is the movie that had made Audrey Hepburn a fashionable movie star.

An elegant woman's shoe - abandoned, not at midnight to beckon a prince, but, mid ankle-stretch, by horrified royalty unable to stoop to retrieve it, for fear of losing decorum in front of her austere procession. It's one of the most understated, classic bits of physical comedy in cinema history. And it's the perfect start to Roman Holiday, director William Wyler and screenwriter Dalton Trumbo's effervescent soufflé of a travelogue, which remains as irresistibly charming as it does deceptively clever, over half a century on. It helps, naturally, that six decades on, our obsessions with not only celebrity culture but Monarchy-mania have only intensified. This makes the film feel simultaneously timely, but also a delightful escape to the ages of pre-digital social media (imagine Princess Ann's antics on the town going unnoticed in the era of Twitter or Instagram ). Trumbo's script crackles with subtly acidic tongue-in-cheek humour and heart, sailing along with breezy abandon. What is a product of its time (in the best possible sense): Princess Ann's claustrophobic, nauseatingly regimented royal life doesn't just poke fun at the disempowering nature of life in the public eye. It serves as perfectly metaphoric for the stifling, ideologically rigid 1950s housewife lifestyle, stripped of all autonomy under the veneer of glamour and elegance. Still, Trumbo nudges this subtext rather than hammering it, keeping the mood delightful, if not frivolous. The Rome locations, shot in crisp black and white, are utterly gorgeous, and tie the entire film's joys up in a sophisticated bow. Audrey Hepburn is a luminous delight here, achingly convincing as both flawless princess, and the exuberant young woman cooped up inside her, ready to burst. She bubbles with infectious joy (and some A+ comedy-drunk acting) throughout, before snapping shut again with mirthless, icy composure, which is all the more heartbreakingly impressive, making her Oscar win here indisputably well-deserved. Bouncing off her, Gregory Peck struggles to overcome being a touch too stiff for a part unmistakably earmarked for Cary Grant, but lends it a clipped charm of his own all the same. Finally, Eddie Albert, in the long-suffering Donald O'Connor 'friend/foil' role, is an adorably acrobatic sensation, brimming with beleaguered pratfalls and beard-yanks galore. If there's a sole complaint to be made, it's that Wyler's luxurious, congenial feel lends the film a more laboured, drowsy, and overlong feel than its sparky plot of hi-jinx on the town deserves. Still, Roman Holiday is one for the ages: airtight, clever, and heartwarming, it's still arguably the romantic comedy to beat, decades down the line, and a cinematic treat worth indulging in for viewers familiar or new. If nothing else, for a film that puts so much stock (ha) in images, that closing shot - long, lingering hallway procession, keeping the audience agonizingly dangling from the bittersweet lure of potential - is a doozy. Ciao, bella. -9/10

As opposed to most reviews, I thought this was one of the worst examples of a bad rom com I've ever seen. What comes to mind;
1. Two wooden actors trying to act friendly.2. A man comes across a sleeping woman in the middle of the night in Rome and isn't startled that she speaks English with some weird accent.3. All the Italians are seen as bafoons.4. The Princess is given a shot to get her to sleep but she manages to get dressed climb out of a castle, go showboating around Rome and finally acts silly.5. It's not that Peck look mature; anyone would look old next to a girl who looks and acts like she's an entitled 14 year old.6. It's supposed to be cute that a young girl basically steals a Vespa, causes traffic problems and then gets away with it. At the dance she manages to bang a guy on the head with a guitar and it's sooooo cute.7. The Princess doesn't want to meet the common folk as everyone seems to think. "I want to do all the things I always wanted to do".8. It always amazed me that Hepburn became as big a star as she did. They could have given her elocution lessons or taught her to speak slightly faster. Until she gets a "Thank you" out you could hold your breath.9. I have a lot more, but it's obviously a rip off of IT HAPPENED ONE NIGHT only not funny and with less interesting characters. It's so similar that the reporter gives up a windfall money wise (the price of the interview vs. The reward for the daughter).....and I felt bad for Eddie Elbert whose sole role in the movie is to get drinks spilled on him and trip each time Peck touched him. He did look good with a beard and had a great name.

One of the best things about Roman Holiday is its cast. Alongside Audrey Hepburn, Gregory Pack, and Eddie Albert's incredible acting, all of the Italian actors in supporting roles act with so much heart and soul that they add great energy and juice to the film.Some of the details like the wonderful silent banter with the florist guy, or the music loving agent who is "crowned with" the guitar were just heartwarming. The scenario works so well that while you feel the uplifting romance in the escapade, you also feel the joy of a paparazzi in every picture taken. The two man's later on mental construction of the news story with the pictures spread on the bed was priceless. In so many aspects Roman Holiday is Hollywood at its best.

Roman Holiday is the most perfect film ever produced. Humor, romance, slapstick, dialogue, and most of all, poignancy. I had never seen an Audrey Hepburn film until a few years ago when my girlfriend (now wife) picked it up on video and said I would like it. I'm a big Gregory Peck fan, so I was like sure, I'll watch it. From the moment Audrey first appeared as the delightfully charming Princess Ann, I fell in love with her. I know that's a commonly used phrase when describing Audrey's performance in this film, but I don't know how else to describe it. I literally fell in love. I'm not a big fan of romantic comedies, and I think most movies are worthless crap that have done more to destroy our culture than advance it. But my god this is the best film I've ever seen! I've probably seen it 10 times now, and every goddamm time I see it I fall in love all over again and in the end my heart is left broken. Audrey and Peck's chemistry is magical. The scenery is beautiful, even in black and white. Dammit, even Eddie Albert is wonderful! Every time I watch this movie I want to hold Audrey in my arms and kiss her and never let her go. I never felt this way about a stupid movie. But I can't help it. I refuse to own it. Why? Because I would spend all my free time watching it, to see if maybe, just maybe, this time they'll end up together. I end up catching it every few months on AMC, after which I'm in a funk for a few days. I know this sounds ridiculous, but this is the only movie that hits me so deeply, so passionately. I'm almost angry that it does so, but what can I do? "Well, life isn't always what one likes, is it?"What also bothers me is why these two never worked together again? Does anyone know? Please tell me. After Roman Holiday, I've found every other Audrey film to pale in comparison. The major fault of all of them is the lack of chemistry she shares with her costars (grouchy Humphrey Bogart in Sabrina; the laughable Gary Cooper in Love in the Afternoon; a decent effort by George Pappard in Tiffany's; the "I-bet-I-can-be-more-suave-than-you" performance of Cary Grant in Charade; I could go on forever). Audrey is wonderful and beautiful as usual, but the films are generally poor. Peck went back to the gritty hero roles (and was perfect in all of them), while Audrey was pawned off to every Hollywood romantic lead. I just don't get it. But then again, I don't think I'll ever get Hollywood.
Feel so sad for the bad ending...They never meet each other again😭

reviews.review_title: One of my all time favourite films..
reviews.content:
Audrey Hepburn is charming and beautiful in this wonderful film. She is totally believable both as a princess, and as a "normal" citizen for a day. From the start we feel that the princess appears to have more human characteristics than the royal people she is surrounded with, e.g. losing her shoe, and also her exhaustion and frustration with having to remember unrelenting daily schedules and routines. This helps to draw us in to her character to such an extent that we later delight in little things such as Anya getting her hair cut, and seeing her discover what it is like to have the freedom of being just a "normal" person.. something that we all take for granted. She thoroughly deserved her Oscar for best actress. Not that this was a one person film, Gregory Peck is also great as the news-reporter, and we genuinely believe that his character goes from initially seeking to profit from the princess, to actually falling in love with her.
The film is successful at involving us with the adventures of the main characters. We feel that we are actually tagging along with the romantic excursions, but not to the point where we feel that we are intruders. Hence we seem to share a lot of the characters' emotions. In the end we develop such sympathy for both characters that we feel their individual pains, and the hopelessness of their situations in that they are denied what they want because of who they are. Perhaps drawing the audience in, to the point where they are able to empathise with the characters, is where a lot of modern romantic films fail.. sure this film might appear dated in it's black & white form on-screen, but the emotions are timeless.. and it more than stands the test of repeated viewing.

The very definition of a classic, Roman Holiday is as irresistibly charming as it is fanciful and even naive. Partly thanks to the beautiful Roman backdrop, which gives every scene a gorgeous background in lively, warm black and white; partly thanks to the fantastic cinematography, way ahead of most films made in the 50's, a time in which a lot of cinema was still being filmed exclusively on set; partly thanks to young Audrey Hepburn and charismatic Gregory Peck, who dominate every scene with incredible stage presence and chemistry. It's easy to point out the film's flawed logic and the holes in the plot, but it's even easier to lose yourself in its beauty and warmth.

I just watched the DVD print. I had actually planned to skim through it, but once the film started, I couldn't help but watch all the way through - for about, oh, the tenth time at least. And it still makes me smile, and laugh, and cry. In the film, 'Anya'/Anne speaks of a lack of sweetness and decency in the world. And you know what? It doesn't sound hokey - just very sad, and very true. The cynicism that abounds everywhere today (especially in film) is suffocating. And 'Roman Holiday' is the sweetest, most decent antidote. There are many bits in the film that stand out: the opening scene where Anne is literally uncomfortable being in the shoes of a princess, the mouth of truth where Audrey's reaction is absolutely genuine, the scooter ride, her very first cigarette, Eddie Albert's photo session with the model 'fishing' in his studio (always cracks me up!), the dance on the barge, the kiss on the river bank, the sudden, passionate yet sad embrace in Joe's apartment - the list is endless. But I think the part that really clinches it for me is when Anne returns to the palace and is being chastised for running away from her duty as a princess. She cuts off the General firmly with something to the effect of "If I were not perfectly aware of my duty to my family and my country, I would not have come back tonight,", here we cut to a sublime close-up where Anne is barely able to contain her tears, and then, "...or indeed ever again." There is the slightest tremor in her voice which belies her composure. Anyone and everyone who thinks/says Audrey Hepburn is not really 'acting' but just 'being herself' in the film, just take another look at this single, remarkable shot - she conveys everything with these four simple words, expressed as only she could have.Bravo!

I'm sure when this movie was made that it wasn't seen as much more than a piece of romantic fluff.  But it has a winning combination of professionalism and spirit that keeps the movie alive 50 years after it was made.Gregory Peck can't bring himself to play the seedy, irresolute reporter that was scripted, and ends up more like Atticus Finch than Hunter Thompson. Still, his portrayal works because the movie needs a straight man to play against Audrey Hepburn's radiant performance.At its most basic, Roman Holiday is a classic of the genre of opposites attract -- young vs. old, foreign vs. native, rich vs. poor.  However, it also works as a hidden identity farce, a simple travelogue for a beautiful city, and a showcase for a solid actor and winning actress.

"Roman Holiday" is an interesting film. It starts slow, showing Princess Anne trying to escape from the bounds of monarchy. She takes one day to herself to explore Rome with her new friend the reporter. This feels like somewhat of a metaphor for Europe as a whole which struggled with war, conquest, and dangerous pretensions during the decades preceding this film in 1953. But by 1953 Europe was beginning to emerge from the wreckage of World War 2 and a more optimistic spirit was birthed. Touring Rome became something possible and desirable again. Unity and harmony were the feelings of the day with the modern European Union getting its start in Rome just four years later in 1957 with a treaty creating the European Economic Community.Returning to the film, it does keep a realism though as illustrated by the ending. I thought that it did a nice job of portraying a fleeting relationship, but some of those can be more meaningful than any other type. I also liked how the reporter and photographer didn't just sell out for the money, they placed their new friendship above monetary and professional success showcasing laudable and rare restraint. Though it is a shame that this film was not shot in color. And the acting was fine, but I am surprised Audrey won an Oscar for this one. So I view "Roman Holiday" as a good film which will make you smile in parts, but not the masterpiece that some say. My rating: 7/10.

reviews.review_title: not even a whiff of communism
reviews.content: This movie is supposed to be based on a story by Dalton Trumbo, who was put in jail because he would not snitch on communist pals. It was during the days of McCarthyism, in which supposedly communist had infiltrated the film industry and......what, really? Were they supposed to smuggle in some hidden communist propaganda in their films? How would that be possible? Take this film, for instance. According to that theory, this is a communist story. How come then, that the only feeling I'm left with is pity for the rich and powerful, who have to live such dreadful lives of duties and no fun at all. Poor, poor princess, jau, jau. Having written this story, Dalton Trumbo deserved to be kicked out from the communist party for being a capitalist spy and not the other way around! We now know, or should know, that Sovietism was not communism. Fidel Castro's Cuba was much closer to communism. The iron curtain was not communism, it was protectionism of power. Nothing hurt the idea of communism more than the Soviet Union claiming to be communist and at the same time establishing the iron curtain. They did it in order to protect their party in which they had invested their lives, not in order to protect communism. It can be argued that communism is at least partly to be blamed. It says: From all according to ability and to all according to need. Who decides that one man needs a castle to live in and another man only a shed? Only power would decide such a thing and that's not the idea of communism. "Prosperity to all" is a better slogan, but that is anarchism, which is maybe the better ism. Communism or anarchism - one thing is for sure - none of them profits from films, that make us feel sorry for the rich and powerful! If I were a communist and had to choose between writing stories like the one for this film and go to jail, I'm not sure what I would choose, provided that the jail was decent with good food and no chance of being raped. In America, such provisions are not given and maybe therefore this film exist???

It's not often that the IMDB average rating matches mine, so this makes the film even better : )Part rich and famous, part lying and adventure, part romance. The combination delivers.Here's my breakdown:STORY:
This reminds me of the Disney animated film "Aladdin" (1992) with regards to a princess and adventure.Yes, they are obviously diverse media and stories, but this facet provides a rendezvous with fun, trouble, and romance.The story here slides back and forth between the intoxicating desire for success and the sobriety of doing what's right.A nice balanced story, and I never was confused about characters, context or direction. It's a bit sad too ... if you have a heart.ACTING:
Peck is the archetype of tall, dark, handsome, and chivalrous. Hepburn, like Grace Kelly, was the quintessential
paragon of beauty, grace, and an insatiable mischievous itch. Here, the pair had good chemistry.Since they consume the screen end-to-end, there's not a lot else, but they did fit nicely together.TEMPO:
Excellent, though on occasion feels slowCINEMATOGRAPHY:
Excellent, and I agree that BW was the way to goDIRECTING / WRITING:
William Wyler was a superb director, and he just does his thing here. On the other side I see three writers, but not
much stands out on their (combined) resumes. I guess three heads were better than one.Is it a good film? Yes.Should you watch this once? Yes.Rating: 8.0.
I love this movie. It's awesome. You should watch this.

This review contains spoilers.Roman Holiday is a romantic comedy movie that premiered in 1953. The film is directed by William Wyler. The movie stars Gregory Peck, and Audrey Hepburn. The movie is about a royal princess and a reporter that take a day out to Rome to see the sights. Ann, the royal princess, is played by Audrey Hepburn. Joe Bradley, the reporter, is played by Gregory Peck.Roman Holiday is a well put together film. The movie's age is not transparent save for the black and white nature of the movie. The movie's plot, direction, characters, and acting are all top notch and timeless. The only age that the movie shows is in its pacing. The movie has a running time of 118 minutes. This running time can feel slow to the fast paced movies of 2018. The movie does utilize the time well and this shows with the chemistry between the leads.The chemistry between Ann and Joe Bradley is unique. That is the movie's biggest strength as
both of the characters writing is well supported by the actors. The entire running time focuses on these two characters and it is well worth the watch. There are many fun situations that the two characters become involved in. I found myself enjoying the comedic moments in the movie a lot. The movie can also switch tones drastically into a more traditional romantic drama. I really felt for Joe Bradley at the end when he gave the photographs' over.I highly recommend 'Roman Holiday'. The movie is one of the best romantic comedy movies across all time.Grade: A

reviews.review_title: What if Eddie Albert had played Joe?
reviews.content: Gregory Peck seemed very stiff and un-romantic in the leading-man role here. I've really liked him in other things, but what if Albert's more lively, light-hearted character had been the object of the princess' affections? I can envision a more entertaining movie under those conditions, but maybe that's not the way things were done in the 1950's maybe the tall, handsome leading man was a must-have. I've read that one of the reasons Peck wanted this film was because he felt he needed to 'lighten up' his image I'll agree with him on that, and sincerely hope he did even more lightening up after it, because there was still room for improvement.Audrey Hepburn might have acted a bit childish and under her implied age at times (mostly in the embassy bedroom scenes, when she seemed to be channeling an eight-year-old), but she was sweet and lovable and filled the role of Princess Ann very well.To be totally honest, I didn't watch this out of any real interest in the film itself, but only for the on-location scenery since I'm going to Rome in six months. I share the sentiments of those who wish it had been in color, but even in black and white it's visually stunning. The best part of the movie was the scenery; the second best part was Eddie Albert. Worth a look for those who enjoy vintage romantic comedy.

reviews.review_title: I can see why Audrey Hepburn was a shoe in for the OSCAR
reviews.content: This was Audrey Hepburn's first American movie.  She is a delight, pixie, elfish figure, and not one of those bosomy dames.  I can see and sense the freshness of her style of acting and grace on the screen.  Her characters naive and participation for adventure is carried out with utmost plausibility and envy.  Gregory Pecks character has honor, and stage presence.  Peck is a man's man.  The scenes are completely shoot in Rome, Italy, and what wonderful backdrop that was.  So scenery was the easy part here.  The characters are strong and believable.  The film is in black and white and I hope that it remains that way.  Everyone can have fun watching this film.

William Wyler's smart romantic comedy Roman Holiday is a movie that redefined that genre at the time this movie was released. The movie stars Audrey Hepburn in an Academy award winning film debut as Princess Ann of Italy who runs away from from her palace for one night while being dizzy at the same time, after she escapes and sleeps on the side of a bridge for a few minutes, and then she encounters an American journalist by the name of Joseph Bradley (played by Gregory Peck).Then the following morning they miss the Prince's interview and instead of the Princess exploring Rome on her own the princess and Bradley end up exploring Rome together along with another journalist named Irving Radovich (played by Eddie Albert). Then after the sunsets and they are at a dinner party all hell breaks loose and a huge fight breaks out because of a few secret service agents forcefully trying to take the princess back to her palace (in which this scene made me think back to the fight scene in John Ford's She Wore a Yellow Ribbon (1949). The one thing I love most about this movie is the chemistry between both Hepburn's and Peck's characters, as well as the music, photography, humor and among other things. Also while watching this movie it made me think back to that Woody Allen movie I saw a few days ago which was Midnight In Paris (2011). But in the end I would recommend this picture for people who like romantic comedies and as well as romance movies in general.

reviews.review_title: One of the best movies ever!
reviews.content: In my opinion, this is one of the best classic movies ever.It stars Gregory Peck and Audrey Hepburn. Just those two names should be enough to make you want to watch this movie. :-)The story is great, it's about a princess (Hepburn) who visits Rome, Italy and meets a reporter (Peck) who wants an exclusive story about her. Pretending that he doesn't know who she is, he hangs around with her hoping to get his scoop. But the plot quickly changes when they fall in love.This movie's called a Romantic Comedy because it's good as a romance and as a comedy... there are plenty of funny scenes, but you don't find yourself wondering why they bothered with the romance like in a lot of other comedy movies.Great camera work, too.It's Not Rated, but I would give it a G. There's nothing dirty in here, and no foul language.
If you don't fall in love with Audrey you have no soul!

Roman holiday is effortlessly entertaining masterpiece, providing 2 hours of pure fun and joy. Audrey Hepburn, in her American debut, plays a bored, tomboyish and posh aristocrat, wanting to explore Rome like an ordinary tourist. Her performance on this film is probably her best- it is easily naturalistic, and there is good chemistry between her and Peck. The comedy in this film is simply done just right- it is funny without descending into unbelievable farce, and at the same time utterly charming, the sort of film which would inadvertently bring a smile to your face. Part of the fun of course is the interesting plot, which puts this naive, tomboyish princess in a new, exciting environment. Rome also features almost as a supporting character- our couple visit the major landmarks, which were filmed on location, delivering a realism which is rare in 1953- most films them were simply shot on a large soundstage. Perhaps this is why the film holds up very well today. Roman Holiday offers immense fun and effortless charm which is sorely lacking in romantic comedies today, where the comedy seems contrived and farcical and the romance takes itself too seriously.

reviews.review_title: Yes you can run around the streets of Rome with a HOT Princess.
reviews.content: Watched this picture with my Daughter which I believe triggered her adventurist side of traveling to far away lands. Definition of the term "Roman Holiday". An instance in which someone experiences enjoyment on account of someone else's suffering or taking a break from the usual lifestyle to see what your missing out on. I had my first of many such experiences but the first time was in early March 1975. Unusually warm day for that time of the season. I decided to ditch school and head to the Mall. I had just gotten paid the day before and deposited my check at the bank. Free with cash in my pocket, I roamed around, went to a couple of clothing stores and ended up at a ticketron office. I wanted to buy Hockey Tickets for the New York Islanders. Unfortunately the system was down so the only way I could buy tickets was to travel to the Nassau Coliseum. Behind the Mall was a fleet of Buses. I randomly asked one of the drivers how to get to the Nassau Coliseum . He told me to take the N32 to Hempstead terminal and switch to the N70 to the coliseum. It was only 10:45 and I thought what the heck. I took the long winding road trip on the buses to the arena. I was at a point of no sudden return. Roman Holiday is about a Royal Princess Ann (Audrey Hepburn) in he first starring role. The picture doesn't tell you her country of origin but from the initial narration the Princess toured England as a guest despite Audrey Hepburn's British accent. Held by a rigorous schedule and itinerary, the velvet chains were pulling the troubled Princess much too hard. The private physician was called to apply a sedative to make her sleep. Instead the agitated Princess escapes the luxurious confines of the Rome embassy to the humble neighborhoods of Rome,Italy. The sedative finally takes effect as Newsman Joe Bradley (Gregory Peck) finds her sleeping on a bench and takes her to his second story apartment. Bradley leaves for his office telling his boss Mr. Hennesey (Hartley Power) with some excuse why he missed the press conference for Princess Ann sees the photo and realizes that the drunk tired woman he brought home is the same Princess in the photo. Joe realizes he's sitting on an exclusive story, gets his photographer friend on the action. Bearded Irving (Eddie Albert) comes by as they pretend to not tell their new guest they know her true identity. Light comedy and flirty conversation takes over most of the picture as the two frolic through the streets of Rome. Joe keeps up his cover as the handsome couple ride a motor scooter and sample the sights of the City of Fountains. The only problem I had was that the movie wasn't filmed in glorious color. Fine screenplay by Dalton Trumbo and this movie also launched a courtship with millions of fans who found little, svelte, elegant, refined, Audrey into their hearts forever. Gregory Peck showed his compassion and humor despite appearing wooden at times. Eddie Albert was also a fine third wheel in this one day adventure along the winding streets of Rome. Watching this film was like enjoying a cup of gelato yet you know you'll soon be done with an empty cup. That being stated I still recommend a viewing on a rainy day.

I think this captures what life must be like at the top of the Royal Family. Always shaking hands, never being allowed to express an opinion and never really doing what you want.Audrey Hepburn as a Princess of an unknown Country sneaks out one night after just taking a sleeping pill and wakes up on a bench. She is discovered by Gregory Peck an American journalist who takes her home and when he discovers that she is a Princess he tries to milk a story out of her.This also works as a travel show for Rome. The City is made to look like the best place for a Princess to spend an incognito day.Very charming film.

reviews.review_title: Film from romance and taking the high road were still a thing
reviews.content: The film comes off oddly credible despite depicting a time when journalists weren't bereft of morals and romance consisted of more than getting drunk at a Jersey Shore club for a few hours together before having sex. Audrey Hepburn exudes girlish charm and doesn't reflexively show us her navel in every scene as she would have to if this were a modern film. Gregory Peck actually plays someone on the horns of a moral dilemma instead of someone who simply follows where the money takes him. You get the sense that in 1953 Italy an English princess could still just about disappear on the streets instead of being torn apart as today's huddled masses would. In short, this breezy, beautiful shot romantic comedy stands as testament to the decline of Western civilization and some of those things that were once good about it.

reviews.review_title: Roman Holiday, Roman Heart and Roman Magic--Eternal City, Eternal Film!
reviews.content: Where to begin with this lovely, enduring film that is destined to live forever? -the pure magic of Audrey Hepburn? --the spectacular beauty of Rome?--the genuinely brilliant and surprising script?--the acting styles of each and every actor displaying such wonderful timing and precision, balancing realism, brilliant comic timing and heartfelt emotions?--the virtuosic direction of William Wyler who, at the drop of a hat, lets the audience laugh with glee at some of the more outrageous situations, behold in wonder the glories of the Eternal City and then feel tears welling up at the bittersweet moments when the day draws to a close and the inevitable march of time and reality intrudes on the fantasy? First of all the film is a miracle of timing--there is not one wasted moment. It is so perfect--that we want to see it again, and again--and each time it feels just as fresh, just as surprising and witty, just as heartbreaking as the first viewing. Most importantly, we the viewer, relate. We're not Royalty in a receiving line waiting to greet dukes and counts and foreign dignitaries....We're not ex-pats in some exotic locale scrounging for a living...and yet, the characters all feel so real to us. Who hasn't felt the pangs of unrequited love? Who hasn't experienced the laudable feelings of loyalty to a lover...to a friend? Who hasn't felt desperate, or lonely, or deliriously happy, or contentedly at peace...these emotions abound in the film, as real to us as they are to these wonderful characters on that silver screen. So many moments to cherish in this film: the genuinely funny opening reception line, Audrey Hepburn's smile and luminous beauty, the first view of sunny Rome from Joe Bradley's plebeian but wonderfully colorful terrace, the great comic persona of Eddie Albert's beatnik photographer, the ancient Roman ruins lit up in the dark of evening, Wyler's textbook perfect filming of the police station episode with just a few bars of the Wedding March heard as Joe Bradley gleefully lies his way out of an arrest of the Princess, the myriad characters--whether the cleaning lady, the landlord, the barber, each with brief but memorable and memorably adorable scenes, that moment of heartbreaking loneliness toward the end of the film, in Joe's apartment when the princess prepares to leave her "new life" and "new love" forever, and the final, amazing scene as the Princess greets the reporters--what a cascade of emotions the characters (and we, the audience!) feel! Its clever and funny one moment as Eddie Albert takes that last picture with his cigarette lighter and the princess gets a quick glimpse of her "photo". Its reassuring and so satisfying, how with a simple sentence across that palace room, Joe is able to convey to the princess that she needn't worry--their story is their story--no one else's to betray or to be regretful about! And in another heartbeat, the scene fills us with heartfelt emotion and tears, as Joe and the princess are as far apart as physical distance and life and their world could make them.....and yet with an eye glance, and a touching few words, and a final loving smile from our radiant princess--they are as close as two human beings have ever been. This is a film to treasure forever. For us film buffs, as someone else has commented upon in these user comments,..in our minds Audrey Hepburn and Gregory Peck are forever young, forever beautiful...and just about to begin their wonderful, enchanting, fun and love-filled day in their and our beloved Rome--a Rome of Heart and Magic and endless possibilities of life and love and happiness.

If you are a sucker for a 1950's romantic comedy like I am, than you will adore this film. Audrey Hepburn's charm shines in this 1953 Oscar winning film. This coming of age movie reminds us to take time for ourselves to remember who we really are and to follow our hearts once in a while. Hepburn plays a sheltered young Princess Anne whose life is structured and planned down to the very last second by her royal staff. While on the Rome stop of a goodwill tour of Europe, the stress of her controlled life finally gets to her. She is given a shot to help calm her down and sleep but before feeling the full effects of the drug, she sneaks out of her room and into the night streets of Rome. Gregory Peck plays a tall dark and handsome struggling American reporter stationed in Rome named Joe Bradley. After a late night of cards, he stumbles upon Princess Anne sleeping on the streets. He attempts to help the young lady home, not yet knowing of her royal status, but realizes she is far to intoxicated to help herself so he brings her to his apartment to sleep it off on his couch. It's not until the next day that Joe realizes that he has the biggest story of his career sleeping in his apartment. He encourages Anne to spend the day out doing everything and anything she has ever wanted to do, all the while Anne thinks she has fooled Joe into thinking she is Anne Smith, the student, but Joe's intentions are to sell his princess story to the press. As the day goes by, he realizes that this private day they have shared means more to him than the price he would get for the story.Spoiler!Anne's day in Rome with Joe helps her discover herself in more ways than she expected. She lives, laughs, and loves her way through Rome with Joe by her side. Most of the scenes with Anne and Joe are shot from a lower angle, I believe this was done to make Joe appear taller and more like a protector to Anne. But, like Cinderella, Anne rushes back by midnight to her royal responsibilities and she must say goodbye to her beloved Joe. In the closing scene, Joe is walking out of the royal press conference being held in a lavish and large room. You see the empty throne over his shoulder getting further and further away. He stops at the end of the room and looks over his shoulder. This signifies the distance and impossibility of his relationship with Princess Anne. The movie is only shot over a 3 day period but you feel as though you have witnessed Anne grow up in front of your eyes from a spoiled Princess to a lovely young woman.

reviews.review_title: ROMAN HOLIDAY Sparkles on New DVD Release!
reviews.content: All one has to do to get some idea of how well loved William Wyler's romantic 1953 comedy-drama ROMAN HOLIDAY is -- is to read several of the Reader's Comments recorded here! Having a Laser Disc copy of this title, I have eagarly awaited its arrival on the DVD format. Several times I have been tempted to order a Hong Kong release. (I'm glad I didn't!) The wait is over as Paramount has released ROMAN HOLIDAY and Billy Wilder's 1950 classic, SUNSET BOULEVARD on DVD, in beautifully restored Collector's Editions that are breathtaking! There is a short "Restoring ROMAN HOLIDAY" featurette that gives one an appreciation for the efforts involved in making this film look and sound like it did when originally released. At age 15, I saw and re-saw ROMAN HOLIDAY many, many times when it was first released. Like most of the movie-going world, I fell in love with Audrey Hepburn in this "star is born" performance. Last year (2001), my wife and I saw a revival of this film at a local theater. Most of the print was fine, but the film was projected in a ratio of 1.85:1, thus destroying the composition of the picture by cutting off the top and bottom of the frame. ROMAN HOLIDAY came out in the year Hollywood was moving from the standard screen format (1.33:1) to the wide-screen (anywhere from 1.66:1 to 2.60:1). This was the year that 20th Century Fox's THE ROBE introduced their CinemaScope process. 1953 was also the year for 3-Dimensional movies -- you wore special glasses and the screen image had depth and things jumped off the screen at the audience. But this was also a year with some outstanding classics still being released in regular format -- films like ROMAN HOLIDAY, STALAG 17, SHANE, FROM HERE TO ETERNITY, MARTIN LUTHER, YOUNG BESS and THE STORY OF THREE LOVES. Now Paramount has released ROMAN HOLIDAY on DVD in a full-frame version that sparkles with its beautiful black and white tones. The sound is excellent -- Mono, yes -- not in 5.1 surround that suits films that were recorded that way -- but in a very nice rendition of the original track (both in English & French). The Featurette, "Remembering ROMAN HOLIDAY" is choice. Included as "Extras" are 3 different Theatrical Trailers; a Photo Gallerie, a Featurette on costume designer, Edith Head (that is also included on the SUNSET BOULEVARD" DVD). Paramount, who is celebrating 90 years, is to been highly commended for this ourstanding restoration. (P.S.: Paramount's WAR AND PEACE is scheduled for a DVD release the first week of Dec. 2002 -- Here's hoping that they have done an equally fine job of restoring that film, which features Audrey Hepburn, Henry Fonda and Mel Ferrer in a epic telling of Leo Tolstoy's famous novel.) ROMAN HOLIDAY is a must own DVD, that should delight old and young alike! Thanks Paramount!

reviews.review_title: a lot of comedy, a lot of love, a lot of warmth
reviews.content: This 1853 movie, filmed on location in Rome, was Audrey Hepburn's first, and she did so very well for a lady in her early twenties, especially when you consider the fact that she was paired with the veteran actor Gregory Peck, and Eddie Albert.It starts off with a fictitious country's young princess (Hepburn)resting in a palace in Rome after a tour of Europe, and in Rome she is very frustrated one night and has a temperamental fit, and thus is given a shot of very strong medicine, so much so that she appears to be inebriated, and just as well be. After sneaking out of the palace she hops a small paddy wagon and rides down a street in Rome, stops in front of a building where she sits on a bench when the American newspaper reporter Tom Bradley (played by Peck)sees her on the bench and later takes her to his apartment. (To indicate how ancient the movie is, nothing lewd takes place there.) He is late for work the next day, but quite by accident in his boss' office he sees a picture of the princess on the cover of a Rome newspaper. He then bets his boss that he will do a story on that "dame", and he in his own mind knows he will win. Naturally, the princess' entourage, a cold group, has no idea where she is, and is worried about her and the fact that she will hold a press conference the next day. In the meantime the princess does not know that Bradley is a newspaper reporter, nor does she know that at the same time he knows that she is the princess. He is, again, going to do a story on her, replete with pictures taken by his friend Irvin Radovich(Albert)who owns his own photo service. Bradley later tells her to take the whole day off and have a holiday, and so they do and it's filled with much fun; the fun ends at a pier where there is a big shindig where, in turn, she tells him that he has been so kind to her and so unselfish. At this point, though there is a fight at the pier which is comical in its own right, the story becomes serious and romantic.Though it is very amusing in so many places, it is, again, also serious in places as well. Whether or not the ending is amusing or serious is something the viewer(s)will have to personally decide. Though the movie is filmed in B&W, the sights around the Eternal City-such as the Victor Emannuel Memorial, the Spanish Steps, the Fountain of Trevi, the Wall of Truth, and the Roman Forum-are still very captivating. And William Wyler does manifest the fact that he is a prolific producer. It is another movie I have watched so very many times, yet do not get jaded despite that.

reviews.review_title: Full of fun and frivolity but wafer-thin in depth
reviews.content: The film which is famous for introducing the world to Audrey Hepburn is a curious mixture of screwball and broader romantic comedy. Hepburn plays European royalty in the form of Princess Ann; a young woman who is stifled by the pomp and routine associated with her role. Therefore, in a fit of frustration and desperation, she takes advantage of an opportunity for temporary escape, just so that she can have a taste of "normal life".Gregory Peck, on the other hand, plays newspaper man Joe Bradley. He's fallen on hard times both financially and professionally and needs a big story to raise his standing in the eyes of his employer. As Joe is making his way home following a long night of gambling, he discovers a seemingly drunk young woman helplessly wandering the streets. Seeing that she is all alone, he resentfully assumes responsibility for her at first. But, eventually, he realises who this young woman is and that the story he'd been looking for may well have just fallen into his lap.A remake of sorts of the depression-era film It Happened One Night (1934), Roman Holiday retains elements of the odd-couple dynamic which sees a royal princess joined through circumstance to working man, Joe Bradley. Yet Hepburn's Princess Ann is much less spiky than Claudette Colbert's Ellie Andrews and Bradley is never close to being as domineering as Clark Gable's Peter Warne; as a result, the developing romance between the leads in this film is far smoother than it was in the original picture, which leads to a slight lowering of the stakes and a definite lowering of romantic tension. Nonetheless, Hepburn and Peck do make a charming couplet.It should also be noted that this film has the distinction of being one of the few major 1950s Hollywood productions to be shot entirely on location in a foreign country, and it makes the most of its surroundings. It moves along at a leisurely pace and delights in the excitement and novelty of Princess Ann's care-free jaunt through Rome. Tourist hot spots are highlighted, most memorably the Bocca della Verità, and space is provided for comical interactions to occur between both the leads and a number of minor native Italian supporting cast members, most of whom speak very limited English. This interplay provides the opportunity for comedy to be generated as much through physical gesture as it does dialogue. The scene in which a flower seller is trying to pedal his wares to Princess Ann being a particularly notable example.Hepburn is at her most whimsical and delightful as Princess Ann, a role which would set something of a blueprint for her Hollywood career. The combination of her youthful, classically beautiful looks, her regal accent and bearing and, just as crucially, her overt appreciation for mild mischief and gaiety make her both a figure of admiration as well as thoroughly relatable. This may well point to the fundamental juxtaposition which made Hepburn such a unique star, she was simultaneously attainable and unattainable, both abstraction and reality. It seems a stretch that someone as sweet, attractive, humorous and good-natured as the persona Hepburn created in this film could truly exist, yet, watching her perform, her presence certainly possesses a high degree of authenticity.The script is well-written with some excellent use of repetition and verbal call-backs. This alongside the physical comedy provides for a thoroughly entertaining experience. The issue with the film; however, is that everything comes together a little too perfectly. It is pure, unadulterated escapism, but escapism through the mostly quotidian. There is certainly charm in this and, even at times hilarity (Hepburn's drunk acting in the early scenes of the film are simply brilliant), but the film never quite delivers on its early promise in which a little more depth was suggested.To elaborate, around 10 minutes into the film, we witness an inner-glimpse into Princess Ann's life in which she is experiencing palpable emotional suffocation. She initially sarcastically and then increasingly disdainfully utters her verbal preparations for her meetings with a series of foreign dignitaries alternating between the reponses of "Thank you" and "No thank you" like some sort of demented royal parrot. Each time she repeats her response, there is an increase in panic and disgust culminating in a disturbing fit of hysteria. In this one scene, one can imagine how robotic and stifling Princess Ann's life must be. She is a free spirit, a lover of spontaneity and authenticity trapped in the life of pageantry and fancily costumed public relations. Alas, after this moment, the film becomes much more light-hearted, which makes the whole thing rather more fun, but also rather less consequential.

Whatever it is that makes movies stars both Audrey Hepburn & Gregory Peck had it in spades. Audrey Hepburn had such a beautiful face, obviously, but that alone is not what made her so appealing to moviegoers. She had qualities that you cannot really train in anyone. She had a radiant smile coupled with enormous warmth & charm such that you really wouldn't know she was an actress playing a part in a movie. She also had such natural grace & class that when playing a princess she was entirely believable. Gregory Peck was in many ways the opposite of Clark Gable. Both were extremely handsome but Gable usually played a rough, tough & overtly sexy type of character. Peck, on the other hand, usually played a more thoughtful gentlemanly type as in this movie. Directed by William Wyler "Roman Holiday" is a timeless romantic comedy &, to my mind, one of the finest movies ever made. Having as a backdrop the eternal city of Rome certainly helps but it is its two principal stars that make this such a fabulous film to watch.

And while he tries to get his story, he also shows her around Rome, and she finally gets the sense of freedom that she had been craving. Of course it is a bit of a love story, but you know that it cannot end well as she is royalty and he is not.
Feeling proud on such a brilliant script ,director , talented cast Audrey Hepburn & Gregory peck . Such a movies are real gem of cinema .

Roman Holiday will forever be considered a classic because it is one of the best movies for three superstar names in the industry: actor Gregory Peck, actress Audrey Hepburn, and director William Wyler. The story revolves around an English princess (Hepburn) who grows tired of the stuffy day-to-day life of royalty and sneaks out during a visit to Rome. An American reporter (Peck) stumbles across her and reluctantly decides to take care of her, not yet knowing who she is. When he finds out, he sees a golden opportunity for his newspaper for an exclusive interview. But then love gets in the way (as always). This movie is like many other light-hearted romantic comedies, but the last scene elevates it to the top tier (remember, no spoilers on this site). Audrey Hepburn plays the part perfectly, as if she is indeed a real princess and I can't imagine anyone else playing Gregory Peck's role as well as he does. Eddie Albert adds some good laughs and Rome is always a great setting. Good movie!

reviews.review_title: A fairy tale set in Rome...
reviews.content:
We should all be so lucky as to experience a holiday as magical and satisfying as the one featured in this movie. Audrey Hepburn stars as Princess Ann, so frustrated with her royal schedule and commitments that she leaves the palace for one night... or so she thinks. Not knowing that she's been given sleeping pills, she ends up falling asleep all over Joe Bradley (Gregory Peck), a hard-nosed reporter who soon realises that he's sitting on the story of the year. What follows is a charming tale set in one of the most beautiful cities of the world, Rome. As Ann/Anya wanders by the Trevi fountain, or visits the Mouth of Truth with Joe, you can't help feeling that there's something magical about the setting. (Obviously, this is helped by the obvious chemistry between the gamine Hepburn and the very handsome Peck.) Everyone should be so lucky as to fall in love in Rome, as Anya and Joe eventually do.Favourite part of the movie: It would probably have to be Joe dumping 'Anya' off his bed and onto the uncomfortable couch, and trying his best to shift her back onto the bed when he discovers that she is actually 'Ann'.
Not to give away the ending, but there is one thing I must say about it: although the premise of the story is itself unbelievable, the ending rings true, incredibly so, and the entire film is the better for it. The last scenes are touching and heartbreaking and inspiring, all at the same time. Well worth the watch.

reviews.review_title: Wow !!! Behind It's Simplicity, Contains A Beautiful Ending !!!
reviews.content: this is my first movie from william wyler. well, to be honest i should say that this movie not so convincing in the early duration. it has a simple plot, with basic and a little bit predictable storyline (except the ending). but as the time goes by, this movie keep flowing and flow and on and on.. maybe because it's simplicity that makes this movie really enjoyable.credit has been given to audrey hepburn. she carry the movie in the early duration. she is the reason that the early movie duration still watchable. she has an inner cherish personality, charismatic actress.well then, the ending has come. i should say that some sentimental scene before the ending were just average in script, but it's simplicity were fantastic. the storyline before that scenes really support the ending scene to be extremely bittersweet dramatic. well honestly i've been touched, nearly as the same level as when i watch city light's ending but not a serious contender. the ending is one of the best movie ending of all time, it was extremely honest, not being forced, powerful, and cherish. i know this movie gonna be exploded in the final duration when i watch the shape of it's storyline.im very sure that this movie gonna hell exploded if being remake ! this movie will have such an adventurous sensation if it is being shoot with colors ! with great cinematography but still using similar classic screenplay, this movie will be unforgettable !!! rome background with cherish and beautiful lighting while not forgetting the superb art-direction will be wonderful. if it will be remake, this movie gonna need a superb actor and actress whose have superb character depth. ryan gosling and natalie portman were the exact player to cast the leads !

The only scene that appears real is the final one; the great hall appears magnificent -- on location and not created.  All other settings are cardboard, especially the view outside Gregory Peck's apartment.  What are those buildings anyway?  And how high up is he?  Audrey Hepburn is way too much to take for an entire film.  Her speaking is so slow and phony.  I think I saw just about all her films.  I liked her in The Nun's Story; her role in Breakfast at Tiffany's is way over the top.  Peck appears as stiff as the scenery and as old as the hills.  And what's with the attention paid to a princess:  ooh -- aah -- let us watch her as she walks toward us, let us ask her about world events, let us not breathe in her presence, let us listen to every syllable uttered and let us memorize her singular answers that will be parroted by future Miss America contestants.  After all, she IS a princess!  And is she speaking English/American to all those men from many nations while in Rome?  Did I miss that explanation?  I know this film is 50 years old so, perhaps, I am a wee bit too harsh.  In the spirit of this holiday season, I offer these few compliments about this film I viewed yesterday.  Peck's eyebrows are not as luxuriant as in his recent appearances and Hepburn does not use a cigarette holder.  At the end when the noble and blessed by birth -- better than anyone else -- princess returns to her fine digs, she is really nasty to the countess and to those two men who cower before her.  I'm wondering who removes her glass slippers and unmakes her 22-mattress bed and brushes 100 times her tresses and sets out her flowing nightie.  Surely "her royal highness" does not.  The premise of this film is amusing, but never will a remake be attempted.  We do not bow before those who think they are royal.  Thanks, John Hancock!

reviews.review_title: It's impossible not to like this movie.
reviews.content:
I've admired Audrey Hepburn for a few years now, but to see her in "Roman Holiday" is a real treat. Not only did she win an Oscar for this movie, her elegance, charm, and genuine demeanor really shine. The plot here is rather simple: An overworked, traveling Princess Ann is finally fed up with her chaotic schedule. After being treated by her doctor (read: sedated!) she goes out and is able to see a bit of Rome before the sleeping sedative hits. And of course, after this, she meets the handsome American Joe Bradley, (a sweet Gregory Peck) and they take the following day off to have a holiday in Rome. It's an old film, and it is a bit old fashioned but unlike other older films, it ages well, and captures just a little bit of Audrey Hepburn's irresistible magic. If you don't fall in love with this movie immediately, as I have...well then, chances are you'll at least fall in love with Audrey. It's almost impossible not to like "Roman Holiday" - even if it is in black and white! 
Being an older film (from the 1950's), the only negative I could possibly give, is that the dialogue is a little hard to understand in some parts. I would think a remastered/cleaned up DVD version would help...or subtitles. But don't let that, along with the absence of modern color turn you off: plenty of great movies are in black and white, and this is one of them. 
Hepburn is a true star.

reviews.review_title: A Royal Tour of the "Eternal City"
reviews.content: Spoilers ahead!This was the film that introduced Audrey Hepburn to the world, and what an introduction it was!  She ended up walking off with the Academy Award for Best Actress for this performance.  Frankly, I think the only other performance in my opinion that was that memorable was Hilary Swank's 1999 turn as doomed teenager Brandon Teena in Boys Don't Cry.William Wyler struck gold with this story of a restless princess with her heart set on freedom, who ends up running from her duties and falling for a "commoner".  I dare anyone reading this to try and NOT think of Diana, Princess of Wales and smile.  Her adventures throughout Rome only take up about fifty or so minutes of this two hour film, so there's not much that she can do other than look at the sights and create mayhem with her two cohorts, Eddie Albert and the irrepressible Gregory Peck.  My favorite scene is the one where Audrey is on a moped and she goes flying off down the street with Gregory Peck in hot pursuit.This film was nominated for ten Academy Awards including Best Picture, Director, Actor and Actress.  Of course, this is the film that shot Audrey Hepburn to stardom.  Films like Breakfast at Tiffany's and Sabrina only cemented her legendary status.My rating: 3 stars
